text: Part 1 Apollo found amusement in many things. From music to games of skill to his long line of lovers, he found ways to pass his godly time when his father did not have tasks for him to complete, or, more often, when he did not feel like completing them. One particular way that the golden youth spent his time was with visits to mortal kingdoms. Apollo wondered how not a single place could rival his home up on Olympus in neither size nor in beauty. Today was a day that Apollo found nothing of interest. His lyre strings had been plucked until his ears were bored with the stale melodies, and his arrows had been fired until he was sick of hearing the thwack that accompanied a flawless shot. He begged his sister to help him find something of entertainment, but she just scoffed and left with her hunters. Thus, he found himself in Sparta, walking through the village and smiling charmingly at everyone he passed. Apollo knew the way he looked; an expensive silk chiton draped flatteringly over his shoulder, sunkissed skin stretched over flat muscle, sky blue eyes that shone with intelligence, and golden locks gleaming in the sunlight. He knew that beauty was enough to make almost anyone do almost anything, and this trip was no exception. Merchants offered him the finest clothes and jewels, insisting no charge. Girls tossed their hair and batted their eyelashes. Youths ran up to him, asking him to come play their sports. Apollo loved knowing mortals would treat him like this, loved knowing that they would always give him something to do. His looks didn't quite match up to Aphrodite or any of her gorgeous offspring, but he certainly came close. Eventually, a young girl, no older than thirteen or fourteen, approached him. An old woman not far behind. "Excuse me!" she called. Her bare feet slid against the dirt as she reached him, dust clouding around her. She didn't pay any mind. Apollo scanned her, noting the thin, rose gold circlet that sat in her chocolate curls. A princess then. "Yes, fair maiden?" he responded, a smile taking up his face. She faltered, a hand coming up to card through her hair. She glanced around, as if she had forgotten what she was going to say. Apollo didn't blame her; his radiance was rather distracting. "Um..." "Princess Polyboea!" The servant finally caught up to her, grabbing her on the shoulder. "Don't run off like that! Your father would have my head if I lost you." At the mention of her father, the Princess came back to herself. "Oh, yes!" Polyboea smiled at Apollo, disregarding her servant, much to her chagrin. "I was wondering if you would like to come back to the castle with me! My father would be pleased to have you." Apollo smiled at her charmingly, and she preened under the attention. "I would love to, Princess. Lead the way." She brightened, and turned, skipping along the path that, presumably, went to the castle. Apollo matched her stride with graceful ease, laughing at the childlike excitement that was rolling off of her. If people had been looking before, now they were downright staring at the combined force of a princess and a god (although his divinity was unknown to them.) Apollo ignored them, instead opting to listen to Polyboea chatter on about this and that while her servant sighed with exasperation. Finally, they reached the gates of the palace. Polyboea ran in, her hair bouncing against her shoulders. She turned, gesturing around the large expanse. "Welcome to our gardens! We house some of the finest flowers in all of Greece." Apollo had to admit that the space was rather beautiful, for a mortal realm. The garden keepers in Olympus would be shamed if the flowers looked like this, but he bit his tongue. They continued the tour, eventually making their way inside the castle. Polyboea immediately led them into the throne room so Apollo could meet her parents. When they entered, his eyes took in the lavish decor. The ceiling was low vaulted and had windows that let in the natural sunlight. Lining the way to the center of the room were several carefully carved white pillars. The walls were decorated with murals of former rulers and battles won. In the center of the room, there were two thrones, where the King Amyclas and Queen Diomede sat. They were talking to a boy, their son most likely. His shoulders were broad and tan, his face chiseled with beauty in the way that princes were. At the sound of the doors opening, the three of them turned. Polyboea ran up to them, her feet padding along the smooth marble floor. "Mother, father!" she called excitedly. "I found this man in the marketplace and invited him over! Isn't he beautiful?" Apollo smiled at the compliment, stepping forward and leaning down onto one knee. It wasn't common practice for him to bow to others, but he would now. "Your Majesties, it is wonderful to be in your palace. Your daughter is as gorgeous as she is kind." He flashed a glance in her direction. Polyboea fiddled with her hair, biting her lip. Diomede smiled at him, standing from her spot. "Oh, that is very sweet of you, stranger." She placed a hand against her heart. "I can tell you are a man of good character, so you are welcome with open arms. We are very glad to have you in our home. If you wish to stay the night, we can have our servants prepare you a room." Apollo nodded, and her smile widened. "Wonderful!" She clapped once, a servant moving from their spot next to her to put together his bed chambers. The Queen gestured in front of her. "This is our son, Argalus, the heir." "It is very nice to meet you, Argalus." Apollo bowed his head, and the Prince nodded curtly in response, not saying a word more. Apollo turned his attention back to the Queen. "If it is alright with you, I think I would like to spend more time in your beautiful garden until dinner is prepared." Diomede gestured for him to go. He turned his attention to Polyboea. "Thank you for bringing me here, Princess." She nodded, her cheeks flushing pink slightly. Apollo exited the throne room, going back out into the expanse of flora. He had to admit, the gardens were rather nice. They were sectioned off in tiers, surrounded by pillars and statues carved out of marble. The flowers bloomed fragrant and plentiful, almost every color imaginable curling along the floors, a simple dirt path leading in between them. Apollo appreciated anything that thrived in his sunlight, so he adored plants. While he was walking through an upper level, he heard the sound of someone humming. Apollo followed the noise, moving to the edge of the section and peering through the columns to get a good look. What he saw made his heart pound. There, sitting in the grass plucking flowers, was the prettiest mortal boy Apollo had ever seen. His hair sat on his head in chestnut curls that caught the sun. His chiton was a shade of lilac, and he had a purple flower resting behind his ear. There were bands of gold that encircled his wrists, ankles, and biceps, extenuating the lean muscle there. And his face. If Apollo thought Argalus had the face of a prince, he hadn't seen anything yet. This boy was so beautiful that he was close to almost being godly. Apollo wondered if, perhaps, this was some sort of secret child of Aphrodite. Apollo, putting on his most radiant smile, stepped down through the pillars. At the sound of rustling grass, the boy turned, his face melting from surprise to dazzled bewilderment in a matter of seconds. Apollo pulled his hair out of his eyes in a practiced, careless movement, stepping closer towards the Prince. "Hello," he said, tone silky. "I am a guest staying in your fine castle, and I thought it would be amiss of me to not introduce myself. What is your name, if you don't mind my asking?" "Um..." The Prince fumbled, clearly thrown off by the alluring beauty before him. Apollo's mouth ticked up in amusement; he had never managed to get this strong of a reaction from someone so handsome. "I...m-my name is, um, Hyacinthus." His voice was soft and rich, sweeter than anything Apollo had ever heard. "Hyacinthus?" Apollo moved to sit down beside him. "That's a lovely name." Hyacinthus glanced up at him through his bangs, golden light of the fading evening catching his eyes, and making them even more enchanting. "...What is your name?" Apollo opened his mouth, a lie on his tongue, but he was interrupted by a yell carrying through the garden, breaking the moment. "Hyacinthus!" a feminine voice cried out. "It's time for dinner!" "Ah, coming Leanira!" Hyacinthus stood, brushing himself off. He looked down at Apollo, who was still lounging against the grass, and extended a hand. "Come with me, I can show you the way to the dining hall." The dining hall, as it turned out, was less of a hall and more of an outdoor area protected from the sun by a roof supported by several pillars. There were two long tables parallel to one another, where six royal children already sat. At the head of each table were the Queen and King. Amyclas looked up to the sound of padding feet, a smile stealing across his face when he saw the pair. "Ah, Hyacinthus, thank you for showing our guest the way." Amyclas turned his attention to Apollo. "I hope he wasn't any trouble?" It was asked in a light tone but clearly asked another, deeper question beneath it. He didn't cause any problems, did he? Hyacinthus looked at him, his eyes filled with fear at his answer, but Apollo just continued to smile sunnily. "He was a splendid guide." He waved a hand through the air, as if to brush off the notion, and Hyacinthus relaxed by his side, so subtly that no one else noticed. They took their places at the end of the table, pulling their plates of meat and bread towards them. Apollo smiled at him over his plate, and Hyacinthus glanced away, his cheeks filling with an appealing flush. He believed that he was going to have a nice time here. Part 2 Apollo stayed for a week, then two. He explored the entirety of the gardens, strolled around the lavish halls of the palace, and visited the outer-city and the market often. The family all warmed up to him, waving a hand when he passed them. All of them, except for one. Hyacinthus didn't talk to him after that night at dinner. Whenever he saw him, his cheeks would flare pink, and he would be gone before Apollo could get a single word out. This frustrated him, of course. All Apollo wanted to do was just talk to Hyacinthus, that was half the reason he was still here, but it seemed like the Prince himself was intent on making sure that didn't happen. Why did the fates hate him? It wasn't until seventeen days, twelve hours, and twenty-two minutes after meeting Hyacinthus the first time-who was counting, though-that Apollo got his first lucky break. He had woken early to watch the rising of Helios's chariot, dawn touching the sky with her soft pinks and oranges, when he was bumped into by the King and his youngest son. "So sorry, sir," Amyclas said, patting him on the shoulder. Hyacinthus averted his eyes, but bowed his head slightly in apology. Apollo released an easy laugh, bright as golden bells. The two of them relaxed instinctively. "It's quite alright, my good King! I was just enjoying this beautiful sunrise. Although, I do wonder what the two of you are doing up so early." His eyes caught on the cloak Hyacinthus was wearing; a traveler's garment. "I was just seeing my son off on a journey to the surrounding city. Some matters that need to be attended to." The King placed a hand on the Prince's shoulder. Hyacinthus flinched under the weight of it. Apollo raised a single brow. "Really? I would've expected Argalus to be the one handling matters such as those, considering he is the heir." "Well normally he would, but he is a bit busy currently with other, more pressing matters. I thought I might use this as an opportunity to introduce Hyacinthus here to some of the duties of being a prince. It's not too important that he does it correctly, anyways." That last part was said quietly, but heard nonetheless. Apollo looked at Hyacinthus, his features etched with embarrassment and shame, and was struck with a sudden idea. "Well, I'm no prince, but I do come from a noble family." This, of course, was half a lie, as the Olympians were the highest royalty there was. "I could come with him and show him the ropes, perhaps?" Hyacinthus looked up suddenly, eyes wide and cheeks rosy. Amyclas didn't notice, a smile stealing across his face. "Why, that's a wonderful idea!" He clapped his hands together. "As long as you don't mind?" Apollo shook his head. "Not at all." Hyacinthus didn't speak to him until they were well out of the castle, buildings in sight. The entire walk over, Apollo could feel the tension radiating off of him. "What do you want from me?!" Finally, Hyacinthus snapped, stopping in place along the path. Apollo turned to face him, feigning innocence. "Whatever do you mean?" Hyacinthus's right eye twitched slightly. Apollo had to bite back laughter at the reaction. "Ever since you came here, you've been following me non-stop. Constantly three paces behind me in the gardens, or sitting down next to me at dinner, or...this!" Hyacinthus huffed, hands thrown up in exasperation. "Why don't you just leave me alone already?" Apollo smiled serenely, which seemed to make the Prince more annoyed. He rolled his eyes, then shoved past him. "I'm ignoring you." Apollo threw back his head and laughed, causing Hyacinthus to speed up his pace. "Wait, no, hold on!" Apollo ran after him, grabbing onto the back of his cloak and checking his stride. "Prince, wait. I did not mean to offend. Will you please talk to me? I hate a silent walk, it reminds me of the numerous times my sister has been tempted to shoot me with an arrow." A moment of silence, then a snort of laughter. Apollo brightened with pride; he knew he was hilarious, but he enjoyed having it confirmed. "Has she actually threatened that?" Hyacinthus asked, amusement still evident in his tone. He turned back slightly, a sign of surrender. "Oh, yes, on numerous occasions." Apollo sighed affectionately, memories of eyes as deep as the night sky glaring at him with rage that could only come from the Goddess of the Hunt herself. "She is, frankly, terrifying." "Hm." Hyacinthus began walking again, slow enough that Apollo could tell he was welcome to stride alongside him, which he did gladly. "...What's the rest of your family like?" Apollo smiled, pleased for the attention. "Oh, where should I even begin?" Part 3 After that day, Hyacinthus broke down his walls, little by little. He stopped avoiding Apollo, and often joined him on his walks in the garden. What used to be icy stilted silence had thawed away to warm laughter and conversation as flowing as the sweet wine at dinner. Apollo was sent with him on many diplomatic involvements, and little by little the snide remarks from Amyclas were reduced, giving way to occasional praise. Every time it happened, Hyacinthus turned towards him, his face happily flushed, causing Apollo's nonexistent heart to stutter. Hyacinthus became more comfortable with him physically, as well. Often, he would place a hand on Apollo's knee while they sat out in the gardens, or a soft hug when they woke and before they went to bed. Once, after an afternoon in the market, there was a soft press of lips to his cheek as they came up on the palace. The next second, Hyacinthus had slipped away, Apollo still stood in dazed confusion in front of the gates. It had been nearly three months. Apollo could feel it in the air, that Zeus was getting annoyed with his absence. He wouldn't be surprised if Hermes was sent looking for him soon, or at the very least Iris. It didn't matter though; he didn't want to leave yet. He wouldn't leave yet, not when there was still so much to learn about Hyacinthus. A storm rolled in, a sign of his father's bad temper. It was gone within a night, but the pounding of the rain and the crack of thunder was enough evidence that its length did not reflect its severity. The morning after, Apollo and Hyacinthus trailed after the servants who worked in the garden, helping tend to the water-tread flowers that had sunk into the supple mud. Just Apollo's divine nature was enough for them to recover quickly, basking in his glow. Amyclas ran into them that night, looking terribly frazzled. He paced up and down the hallway, muttering wildly, and barely spared the two of them a glance when they entered. "Father, calm down, what's wrong?" Hyacinthus walked up to him and placed a steadying hand on his forearm. The King seemed to melt under the weight of it. "A messenger came in from one of the surrounding farm towns a few minutes ago. All the crops have been flooded." He raked a hand through his graying hair. "I don't know what to do. Aragalus is away, the rest of your brothers are terribly busy with their studies, and I'm too old to make a journey that far. But if I don't send someone, then this will never be sorted out, and food won't make it out to the city..." Amyclas trailed off, looking exceedingly more worried. Hyacinthus considered this information, tapping a finger to his cheek. "...You could send me." Amyclas scrunched his nose at him, a knee-jerk reaction that he schooled off his face. "My dear son, I know you have been doing rather well recently, but this matter is really rather delicate, and you are still not the best at negotiations." Hyacinthus huffed at the King's claim, crossing his arms. Apollo placed a soothing hand on his shoulder. "I would go with him, if it makes you feel any better," he said. Amyclas looked up at him. "Seeing as you don't really have any better options, I would like to be of some assistance." Amclas nodded slightly, placing a hand to his mouth as his muttering started again, much less frantic this time. "Yes...I believe that could work out well. If you're there, then you can, yes..." He smiled up at Apollo. "This is wonderful! Thank you for your help, uh, hmm..." The King paused, a puzzled expression on his face. "...You know, I don't believe I ever caught your name, after all this time." Apollo smirked at him, bright and reassuring. Amyclas blinked against the radiance that he was off putting, his face turning relaxed and his eyes glazing over. "I never offered it," Apollo responded. Amyclas nodded in a dazed fashion. "I-yes, that seems perfectly reasonable-I do believe I may have overstepped-well, I mean I...I seem to have forgotten what we were talking about." Amyclas scratched his head thoughtfully. Apollo laughed. "Oh, don't worry about that now. It is getting late, however, and we need to be off in the morning. You should go get some rest." He bowed to Amyclas, who nodded, a little bit hesitantly, and began walking off towards his chambers. Apollo gently pushed the space between Hyacinthus's shoulder blades, where his hand still lay. "Come along, Prince, let me walk you to your room." Hyacinthus looked at him with an odd expression. "...Okay..." Hyacinthus said, a little questioning. Apollo brushed off the strangeness. He was probably just a little tired. The next morning, the three of them met in the courtyard. Amyclas fiddled anxiously, repeating the same instructions multiple times in a row, or checking their rations even though he had already checked twice. Apollo stroked the side of his horse's head, gently. "Father." Hyacinthus caught the King's hand from where it shuffled through their bags for what had to be the fifth time. "It will be alright. With the two of us there, what could go wrong?" Amyclas bit his lip. "Well, I just need to make sure that you, I mean, both of you are very competent, but..." Amyclas trailed off, to which Hyacinthus sighed. "Please, just put a little faith in me? Just this once?" Hyacinthus begged. Amyclas stared at his son, eyebrows furrowed, before slowly nodding. "I...yes, I can do that." He pulled his hand away, and turned to Apollo. "You will make sure that things run smoothly?" "Do not fret, King. I will make it my highest priority." Apollo smiled at him. Amyclas nodded again, then glanced between the two. "Okay, yes. Well, have a good journey, please come home by tomorrow evening." Amyclas let out a breath, then turned towards the doors. Hyacinthus bowed his head. "...Good bye, my son." The next moment, he was gone. Hyacinthus heaved a heavy sigh, his shoulders drooping. He looked up at Apollo and smiled, exhaustion etched into the creases of his eyes. "Come along, companion. It is time to begin the journey," Hyacinthus said, slinging his bag over his shoulder and pulling himself onto his horse's back. Apollo followed suit, and soon the two of them were on the way, easy conversation flowing between the sound of hoofs hitting well packed dirt. Somewhere on the outskirts of the city, Hyacinthus fell silent. Apollo could sense heavy tension strung through the air. He fumbled for a way to cut it. "Um..." Hyacinthus turned towards him, eyes flashing in the morning light. He looked almost ethereal. "I've been wondering about why you and your father are so...?" Apollo winced. Clearly, spending time around mortals had made him lose some of his tact. Hyacinthus turned away from him, eyes hooded. "You don't have to tell me if you don't want to, but I just thought-" "It's alright," the Prince cut in. "I'll tell you." He looked up at the sky where the morning light turned from golden to sweet yellow as the day wore on. "A few years ago, my father presented me with a potential spouse. He was exuberant that his youngest son was engaged. It was my job to court her, as her father had not yet decided who she would marry. I tried as hard as I could to charm her, and I think that it would've worked out, if..." Hyacinthus hunched his shoulders in shame. "If I hadn't messed everything up." He said this last part very quietly, like he didn't want Apollo to hear. However, he heard nonetheless, his stomach twisting from the sheer pain in Hyacinthus's voice. "Messed everything up? How?" Hyacinthus huffed, clenching his fists. "I wasn't interested in her, but I figured that it was better to go along with my father's whims. However, the night that I was supposed to ask for her father's hand in marriage, I began to feel guilty. She was always so happy to see me, and I could not return the feeling. I thought she might understand, so I told her my woes, hoping she would still marry me even if I did not love her." He bit his lip. "I still remember her running off, crying." Apollo watched him, a crease in between his brows. "So...then what happened?" "I was so ashamed that I went home without even talking to the King. My father was furious with me. He wouldn't talk to me for months. I might've even been thrown out if it hadn't been for my mother. And now..." Hyacinthus broke off with a sigh. "Well, I think you get the idea." Apollo turned away from him, considering. "...Once my father actually did throw me out." Hyacinthus turned to him in shock. "Really? You?" Apollo laughed at that. "Yes, me. He was furious with me, and he sent me to live with some farmers for a few months until he deemed it appropriate for me to return." He smiled fondly at the memory. "An overreaction, if you ask me, but he seemed to think it was necessary." Apollo felt a measure of pride rush through him when a small grin stole across Hyacinthus's face. "I just didn't really expect you to be the type who gets in trouble. You just seem so...good." Apollo giggled, considering how untrue that statement was. "You would be surprised." He sighed, a lazy smile spreading across his face. "Although, he never tried to get me to marry." "Oh." Hyacitnhus stroked his fingers mindlessly over the hair of his horse's neck mindlessly. "Why not?" "It was never very important to him," he responded. "Although, that doesn't mean I haven't pursued romance." Apollo let out a breezy laugh. Hyacinthus was silent for several moments, and when Apollo looked over, he almost looked embarrassed. "What about you?" Apollo saw Hyacinthus flinch at the question. "What about me?" "Well, I know there was that Princess, but have you ever pursued romance, just for, you know, yourself?" Hyacinthus began to shake his head, and then stopped, face considering. "...Kind of?" Apollo smirked at him. "What's that supposed to mean?" "Well..." He raked a hand through his hair. "There was an event, but...it's not what you're talking about." Apollo raised an eyebrow. "Elaborate?" Hyacinthus glanced up at him, licking his bottom lip. "...You're not the first person who visited the palace recently. Last summer, there was another nobleman, who I ended up becoming quite close to." Apollo felt his eyes widen, his stomach twisting just barely. "Really?" Hyacinthus nodded. "Yes. I loved his company; I thought of him as my closest friend and I thought he felt similar, but one day he..." Hyacinthus paused, swallowing, and then abruptly switching topics. "At some point, he told me he was a god. Zephyrus, the West Wind." Apollo tried to suppress the scowl threatening to take over his face. "I accepted it quickly. It didn't make him a different person, was what I thought. But then..." This time, when he paused, he didn't start again. "Then?" Apollo prompted. "He told me was in love with me," he said this quietly, as if he couldn't bear to admit it. "And when I couldn't return his feelings, he..." Hyacinthus sucked in a breath. "He was angry. He told me that I was being selfish, and that I would never find anyone like him, because he was divine." His fists had curled into fists, knuckles white. "Finally, he left, but he told me that when I came to my senses, I could call upon him. I spent the rest of that summer locked away in my room, I couldn't stand to face anyone." "Oh, Hyacinthus," Apollo sighed, wishing he could reach out and embrace him. "It was not your fault, you know." Hyacinthus gave a slight nod. "Of course he would be like this," Apollo mumbled, hoping it wouldn't be heard. To no avail. "What do you mean, 'he would be like this'?" Hyacinthus narrowed his eyes at him. Apollo fumbled for a plausible explanation. "Oh, well, that's just what I've heard. You know, how people talk about the Gods." Hyacinthus furrowed his brows. "...Right." The air between them hung heavy and quiet for a moment, suspicion apparent in Hyacinthus' face. Apollo felt discomfort creep through him, spreading over every inch of his body. "Anyways, how about we talk about something more pleasant?" he finally said, if only to fill the itching silence. Hyacinthus narrowed his eyes. "How-how far are we from our destination?" The heavy gaze was finally broken, the Prince looking out to the horizon. "Still at least half a day's journey. We'll need to stop to eat soon." "Oh, can we stop soon? I'm starving!" Apollo dramatically flung a hand to his forehead. An incredulous laugh left Hyacinthus' mouth. "We had breakfast an hour ago!" Apollo grinned at him. Hyacinthus rolled his eyes, and the previous conversation was forgotten. They reached the nearest village hours later, when the sun began to sink below the horizon. The two were led to a small set of dingy stables on the edge of the town where they kept their horses. Hyacinthus grinned at Apollo as they walked out, heading to the first plot of land that was affected. They did that for the rest of the evening, going around town and asking the farmers what supplies they would need to get their growth back on track after the storm. When they were finished, they took a stroll around, chatting amicably about nothing at all. Apollo led them away from the actual community at some point, and into the thick forest to the west of the village. "My mother used to take me and my siblings here all the time," Hyacinthus said as they weaved through trees. The last of the sun's honey glow had faded, leaving nothing but the moon's silver light peeking through the leaves. "I don't remember why, but when we had the time, we would take trips out here and stay in the forest for a day. Back when I was still small enough to ride on the back of a cart." Apollo considered this. "My father never took me anywhere. I went where I pleased, sometimes with my sister, sometimes with one of my half brothers. My family was never close enough to all go anywhere together." "What about your mother?" Hyacinthus looked up at him through thick lashes. "I was not allowed to see my birth mother often, and my step-mother, well..." Apollo trailed off, thinking of Hera's cold sneer whenever she saw him. "She was not exactly fond of me, being one of her husband's bastard children." "Oh." Hyacinthus was reduced to silence by that, eyes contemplative. "It's alright, though," Apollo intercepted. "I still have my siblings. And besides, if I was not able to go where I pleased, I would never have met you." Hyacinthus smiled at him, but he seemed quiet for the rest of the walk. Little over five minutes later, the trees parted, giving way to clearing where the canopy broke. The moonlight shining down on the grass made it almost look blue. "Beautiful," Apollo breathed, stepping into the ring of trees. "The perfect place to practice archery, or play discus." He tapped a finger to his lips. "Hyacinthus, do you think we could-" He turned on his foot, a smile on his face, but it faded when he saw Hyacinthus's expression. It was tight and confused, and a little bit hurt. Apollo walked closer to him gingerly. "Hyacinthus, what is wrong?" Hyacinthus looked at him, eyes searching. Evidently, he didn't find what he wanted, because he looked back down at the ground, a sigh on his lips. "Hyacinthus?" "I think I know what you are." The statement was sudden, seemingly out of nowhere. Apollo nearly took a step back at the conviction that overtook his features. He swallowed. "Really?" he asked. Hyacinthus nodded. "Whatever do you mean?" "I mean..." Hyacinthus pulled at his hair, pacing. "There are all these things about you. Like how you've never told anyone your name, despite being here for so long, or the stories you tell about your family, or the way..." Hyacinthus trailed off clearly embarrassed. "...The way you look, and how everyone treats you. Sometimes, it seems like you change everyone's mood with a smile. And when we discussed Zephyrus, you almost acted like you've met him." Apollo's shoulders were drawn up to his ears, nerves flaring. "...So, what do you think I am?" he finally mustered up the courage to ask. Hyacinthus clenched his eyes shut for just a second, and then looked up, surety in every inch of his features. "You're a god, aren't you?" Time simultaneously seemed to stop and speed up all at once, an eternity wrapped in what could only be a few seconds. The wind quit whistling, and the trees stopped swaying. In that instant, the world was quiet, listening. Apollo finally broke the silence after another moment with a sigh. "...It would be easy to deny, but it is true. I am a god, the God Apollo." He clenched his fists as he said it, looking to the ground in shame. Hyacinthus nodded, resigned, then kept nodding, bracing himself against a tree. Apollo could see in the faint silver moonlight that his eyes had become glassy. He nearly took a step forward, to try to comfort, but thought better of it. "Listen, Hyacinthus, I didn't mean to...I mean, I didn't know about what Zephryus...you have to understand-" Apollo stopped when he heard a watery chuckle, then another. He stared at Hyacinthus in shock as he dissolved into nearly hysterical laughter. "Hyacinthus?" "Gods, just shut up," Hyacinthus cut in, gulping for air. There were still traces of amusement in his tone. "You -you are just such an idiot. I can't even believe it, you are so stupid." In one quick movement, he pulled himself away from the bark of the tree he was leaning on, striding over to Apollo. "What are you-" Hyacinthus grabbed the front of his chiton, pulling him down. His lips were soft and warm, and his hands were smooth. They moved from Apollo's tunic to the back of his neck, pulling him closer. Apollo felt himself wrap his own hands around Hyacinthus' waist in return, his eyes sliding shut. His mouth was sweet under Apollo's, like long walks under the sun, and flowers in the garden. Even under the dark blanket of the night sky, golden light poured through his body, burning away everything until there was only these few seconds. Hyacinthus pulled away after another moment, resting his forehead against Apollo's. There was a constellation of browns and golds in his irises. "For the record," he breathed, "I never thought that you were here because of Zephyrus. You don't seem like the type to do something for someone else's needs." Apollo felt a very undignified snort escape him, to which Hyacinthus smiled. "You would probably be right about that." Apollo smoothed a thumb over his cheek. "I'm far too selfish to do such a thing." "I never said you were selfish." "Yes but it was implied." Hyacinthus rolled his eyes at Apollo's grin. "You are insuffera-mmph!" Apollo cut him off with another kiss, which he quickly melted into. He pulled away as quickly as he came, leaving Hyacinthus dazed. "Oh, so I'm not selfish, but I'm insufferable?" "Apollo!" Part 4 One month later, Apollo went back home. It was the last thing he wanted to do, but he could tell that he was walking on the edge of his father's temper, and he needed to come back to his duties. Olympus was darker than he remembered. Slate gray towers curved upwards, endlessly, into the clouds. Gold covered roofs sat high above, untouched by the light of the sun. The gardens were beautiful, but almost soulless, contained into perfect rectangles between precisely carved marble floors and columns. Just five months ago, Apollo believed that there was no place more stunning than Olympus. Everything pristine and perfect, glistening in the eye of his childhood. He could go anywhere in the world, and still he chose here. A place fit for the greatest of Gods he used to say. But at some point between first seeing golden brown eyes and staring into them under a starry sky, he changed his mind. It was quiet too, lacking the bustle of servants and royal children, and the distant hum of a city. Gods fluttered in and out, never time for more than a hello, always on the move. It made Apollo dearly miss long walks through unkempt flowers, the feeling of soft mud under his feet, and endless conversations that led everywhere and nowhere at all. Zeus was pleased when he came back, muttering a single phrase when he ambled back into the throne room. "I'm glad you've remembered your duties." Apollo simply bowed his head, walking out before another word could be spoken. It wasn't that he had forgotten them. From the moment he left, he knew he would have to come back home. Truly, he had never thought it would take this long to finally return. He wouldn't stay for long, however. He had promised Hyacinthus, with a kiss to the temple, that he would come back to Sparta as soon as he could. Hyacinthus had simply smiled at him, clutching Apollo's hand where it was placed on his cheek. The memory just made him more restless to leave. For now, though, he was confined to aimlessly wandering the vast halls of Olympus, and trying to find where all the light and music went. Maybe, he thought, it was never there to begin with. Days turned into weeks, weeks into months, and still everything remained lifeless. He walked to the edge of the mountainside, where pillars gave way to a perfect view. The fading glow of day was giving way to soft violet that would soon turn to inky black. Even the sky no longer held the same beauty as it once did. The bruising purple only led his mind back to a lilac chiton, the bottom covered his bits of dried mud from running through the gardens all day. A rustle of fabric behind him brought Apollo back to himself. He turned on his heel, expecting Artemis or even Hermes, finally with a moment of free time to question where he had been for five long months. Zephryus stood before him, straightening his tunic with deft fingers. Apollo felt his lips turn down at the sight of him. "Need something?" he asked, watching Zephrus closely. The God of the West Wind looked displeased, dropping his hands down to his sides. His eyes, the color of ambrosia, narrowed at him in clear distaste. "You don't deserve him." Cutting right to the chase then. Apollo nearly sneered. "I think he can decide who does and doesn't deserve him." His words were spat in low, venomous tones. Zephryus didn't back down. "He'll see the truth eventually." He stepped closer. "He'll realize that you are nothing more than pomp and arrogance, and that I am the only one for him." Apollo laughed, sharp and cruel. "He will never return your affections, he told me so himself. You are nothing to him. Just a bitter memory." Zephryus bit his lip, looking down, and Apollo knew he had struck a nerve. "You know nothing," he said quietly. "I love him with all my heart, and you have no right to take him away." Apollo surveyed him quietly for a moment. "Unfortunately, it is not enough." Zephryus scoffed, petulant, and the next second, he was gone. Apollo thought he should feel very smug that he had managed to make Zephryus run off with his tail between his legs, but all that he felt was longing. He looked around at his home, and longed for wild gardens, long walks, and Sparta. He longed for Hyacinthus. His father could deal with his absence, he decided as he disappeared in a flash of golden light. Sparta was just as bright as he remembered. Now, in the late hours of the evening, the market had fizzled out to just a few people, meandering through stands that stayed open in the hopes of extra business before night fell. The way down to the palace was a short distance, and with every step, Apollo's heart felt lighter and lighter. The unpleasant conversation with Zephryus felt forever away, and soon the castle loomed over him. Apollo didn't bother to make his reappearance known to the King and Queen, instead opting to begin searching the gardens. Every flower seemed extra vibrant, as if welcoming him back home. Apollo felt a grin slip onto his face despite himself. After five minutes of strolling aimlessly, he heard the sound of humming, so familiar to him after all this time. This tune was melancholy and slow, swooping down into depressing minor chords. He followed it, breaking out into a run as he got closer. Finally, he found him, relief and joy finding its way into his chest. Hyacinthus sat in a patch of grass, staring down at his fingers twirling a flower as he hummed absently. Apollo slid to a stop when he saw him, and he looked up suddenly, the melody abruptly being cut off. Silence wrapped around them, as the Prince stared at Apollo, still as a statue. "Apollo," he breathed. "You're back." Apollo inclined his head. "I'm back." A breath, a moment. Then, Hyacinthus jumped to his feet and ran into Apollo's arms. Apollo picked him up easily and twirled him around, as Hyacinthus's gleeful laughter rang bright through the garden. When Apollo stopped moving, Hyacinthus sank down to give him a languid kiss. "I missed you," he mumbled against Apollo's lips. Apollo hummed in response, pulling his lover closer. They stood there, in that garden, for what could have been eternity, just taking in each other after far too long. Eventually, they went inside, where Amyclas told Apollo how pleased he was that he had returned, before the two of them slipped away to Hyacinthus's bedchamber for the night. The next day, they went to the market, walking from stand to stand, sides pressed together as they chatted cheerfully with the shopkeepers who offered their wares in excited tones. Then two days later, they found themselves in the city, walking around and enjoying the buzz of life. A week after that, they left on a trip to the outer farmlands, where they spent several days tucked away in a cozy little inn, staying out late and sleeping in until the sun had reached up high in the sky, stifling heat waking them. Apollo decided during that time that he would leave Sparta again, no matter what his father said. This was the most joy he had felt in his entire life. He should've known it couldn't last forever. One day, they found themselves back in the clearing in the woods where it all started, sunlight pouring generously down onto them. They brought a discus with them, laughing as they tossed it back and forth, grass rustling beneath their feet. Apollo threw it, and Hyacinthus easily caught it in his hand, satisfaction flitting over his face when stone hit his palm. He grinned, walking back across the field to Apollo, and giving him a quick kiss. "Wonderful job, my love," Apollo said, tilting Hyacinthus's chin up towards him. His smile widened, and he batted Apollo's hand away. "Oh, come now, I only caught it because you've been going easy on me," Hyacinthus retorted, pulling away from him abruptly. Apollo pouted, to which Hyacinthus laughed. "Don't give me that look, you wanted to play today. And I want you to throw it with some of that 'godly strength' you supposedly have." "Hyacinthus," Apollo walked back towards him, taking the discus from him. "If I threw this with my full strength, I would split the very mountains. My father would not be pleased." Hyacinthus clasped his hands together, pleading. "Just a little bit more strength?" Hyacinthus stared up at him, eyes wide, and Apollo felt his knees go weak. He had never been this enthralled with anyone in his entire godly life. He sighed. "Okay." There had never been another option but to surrender from the start. He winded up, and tossed the discus, employing some of his divine power to make it go twice as far as it normally would. Hyacinthus chased after it, laughing joyfully as he came closer and closer to it, outstretching a hand to make a brilliant catch. Then, something went wrong. The wind, pleasantly rustling the trees, turned on them, blowing in the opposite direction with force enough to knock down a house. In an instant, the discus had whipped around to face Hyacinthus, quickly gaining speed as it shot towards his temple. There was a dull thud and Hyacinthus lost his footing. A scream may have torn its way from Apollo's throat, but he couldn't hear over the blood suddenly rushing through his ears. He was moving before he could think, his feet flying over the grass in a burst of adrenaline, and Hyacinthus landed limply in his arms moments later. He sank down, pulling his lover's head onto his lap. "It's okay, it's okay, I can fix you," he babbled, his hand already sticky with Hyainthus's blood, red and mortal. Distantly, he noticed that the sky had gone dark, but his head was buzzing too much to care. Hyacinthus reached a hand up weakly, stroking away tears that Apollo hadn't realized were there with a thumb. He smiled, eyes hooded. "It is alright, darling." He spoke softly, his voice hoarse and eyes glistening. "Everything will be alright." "No, no, I can fix this. I have to. I mean," Apollo placed his hands to Hyacinthus's chest, drawing up his powers, still mumbling on. "What's the point of being a god if I can't?" He tried and tried, but his magic refused to enter Hyacinthus's body. "No!" he cried, pushing harder. "This has to work! Fates be damned, I will save you!" "Apollo." Hyacinthus moved his chin, forcing him to look him in the eye. "It's okay. I am mortal, this was bound to happen." Apollo stared down at him as realization set in. "I...I can't save you," he whispered, numbness washing over him like a tidal wave. Hyacinthus simply nodded once, still smiling sadly. "No, you can't." His voice was getting softer, and his limp hand dropped down to his chest. "And that's okay." Apollo looked at him for just a moment more, then leaned down, placing a soft kiss against his forehead. "Goodbye, Prince." When he pulled away, the light had left Hyacinthus's eyes. For a moment, he felt nothing. Then, sobs wracked through his body, and he doubled over, laying against the corpse's chest as his shoulders heaved silently. Around them, flowers bloomed, purple and red, all around the clearing. They were bright against the dark, ashen gray sky, the only spot of color in an instant when all light had left the world. In that moment, there was only this: a god and his lost love in a field of flowers, the wind whistling a regretful melody through the trees.
sentences: Part 1 Apollo found amusement in many things.

From music to games of skill to his long line of lovers, he found ways to pass his godly time when his father did not have tasks for him to complete, or, more often, when he did not feel like completing them.
One particular way that the golden youth spent his time was with visits to mortal kingdoms.
Apollo wondered how not a single place could rival his home up on Olympus in neither size nor in beauty.
Today was a day that Apollo found nothing of interest.
His lyre strings had been plucked until his ears were bored with the stale melodies, and his arrows had been fired until he was sick of hearing the thwack that accompanied a flawless shot.
He begged his sister to help him find something of entertainment, but she just scoffed and left with her hunters.
Thus, he found himself in Sparta, walking through the village and smiling charmingly at everyone he passed.

Apollo knew the way he looked; an expensive silk chiton draped flatteringly over his shoulder, sunkissed skin stretched over flat muscle, sky blue eyes that shone with intelligence, and golden locks gleaming in the sunlight.
He knew that beauty was enough to make almost anyone do almost anything, and this trip was no exception.
Merchants offered him the finest clothes and jewels, insisting no charge.
Girls tossed their hair and batted their eyelashes.
Youths ran up to him, asking him to come play their sports.
Apollo loved knowing mortals would treat him like this, loved knowing that they would always give him something to do.
His looks didn't quite match up to Aphrodite or any of her gorgeous offspring, but he certainly came close.
Eventually, a young girl, no older than thirteen or fourteen, approached him.
An old woman not far behind.
"Excuse me!"
she called.
Her bare feet slid against the dirt as she reached him, dust clouding around her.
She didn't pay any mind.
Apollo scanned her, noting the thin, rose gold circlet that sat in her chocolate curls.
A princess then.
"Yes, fair maiden?"
he responded, a smile taking up his face.
She faltered, a hand coming up to card through her hair.
She glanced around, as if she had forgotten what she was going to say.
Apollo didn't blame her; his radiance was rather distracting.
"Um..." "Princess Polyboea!"
The servant finally caught up to her, grabbing her on the shoulder.
"Don't run off like that!
Your father would have my head if I lost you."
At the mention of her father, the Princess came back to herself.
"Oh, yes!"
Polyboea smiled at Apollo, disregarding her servant, much to her chagrin.
"I was wondering if you would like to come back to the castle with me!
My father would be pleased to have you."
Apollo smiled at her charmingly, and she preened under the attention.
"I would love to, Princess.
Lead the way."
She brightened, and turned, skipping along the path that, presumably, went to the castle.
Apollo matched her stride with graceful ease, laughing at the childlike excitement that was rolling off of her.
If people had been looking before, now they were downright staring at the combined force of a princess and a god (although his divinity was unknown to them.)
Apollo ignored them, instead opting to listen to Polyboea chatter on about this and that while her servant sighed with exasperation.
Finally, they reached the gates of the palace.
Polyboea ran in, her hair bouncing against her shoulders.
She turned, gesturing around the large expanse.
"Welcome to our gardens!
We house some of the finest flowers in all of Greece."
Apollo had to admit that the space was rather beautiful, for a mortal realm.
The garden keepers in Olympus would be shamed if the flowers looked like this, but he bit his tongue.
They continued the tour, eventually making their way inside the castle.
Polyboea immediately led them into the throne room so Apollo could meet her parents.
When they entered, his eyes took in the lavish decor.
The ceiling was low vaulted and had windows that let in the natural sunlight.
Lining the way to the center of the room were several carefully carved white pillars.
The walls were decorated with murals of former rulers and battles won.
In the center of the room, there were two thrones, where the King Amyclas and Queen Diomede sat.
They were talking to a boy, their son most likely.
His shoulders were broad and tan, his face chiseled with beauty in the way that princes were.
At the sound of the doors opening, the three of them turned.
Polyboea ran up to them, her feet padding along the smooth marble floor.
"Mother, father!"
she called excitedly.
"I found this man in the marketplace and invited him over!
Isn't he beautiful?"
Apollo smiled at the compliment, stepping forward and leaning down onto one knee.
It wasn't common practice for him to bow to others, but he would now.
"Your Majesties, it is wonderful to be in your palace.
Your daughter is as gorgeous as she is kind."
He flashed a glance in her direction.
Polyboea fiddled with her hair, biting her lip.
Diomede smiled at him, standing from her spot.
"Oh, that is very sweet of you, stranger."
She placed a hand against her heart.
"I can tell you are a man of good character, so you are welcome with open arms.
We are very glad to have you in our home.
If you wish to stay the night, we can have our servants prepare you a room."
Apollo nodded, and her smile widened.
"Wonderful!"
She clapped once, a servant moving from their spot next to her to put together his bed chambers.
The Queen gestured in front of her.
"This is our son, Argalus, the heir."
"It is very nice to meet you, Argalus."
Apollo bowed his head, and the Prince nodded curtly in response, not saying a word more.
Apollo turned his attention back to the Queen.
"If it is alright with you, I think I would like to spend more time in your beautiful garden until dinner is prepared."
Diomede gestured for him to go.
He turned his attention to Polyboea.
"Thank you for bringing me here, Princess."
She nodded, her cheeks flushing pink slightly.
Apollo exited the throne room, going back out into the expanse of flora.
He had to admit, the gardens were rather nice.
They were sectioned off in tiers, surrounded by pillars and statues carved out of marble.
The flowers bloomed fragrant and plentiful, almost every color imaginable curling along the floors, a simple dirt path leading in between them.
Apollo appreciated anything that thrived in his sunlight, so he adored plants.
While he was walking through an upper level, he heard the sound of someone humming.
Apollo followed the noise, moving to the edge of the section and peering through the columns to get a good look.
What he saw made his heart pound.
There, sitting in the grass plucking flowers, was the prettiest mortal boy Apollo had ever seen.
His hair sat on his head in chestnut curls that caught the sun.
His chiton was a shade of lilac, and he had a purple flower resting behind his ear.
There were bands of gold that encircled his wrists, ankles, and biceps, extenuating the lean muscle there.
And his face.
If Apollo thought Argalus had the face of a prince, he hadn't seen anything yet.
This boy was so beautiful that he was close to almost being godly.
Apollo wondered if, perhaps, this was some sort of secret child of Aphrodite.
Apollo, putting on his most radiant smile, stepped down through the pillars.
At the sound of rustling grass, the boy turned, his face melting from surprise to dazzled bewilderment in a matter of seconds.
Apollo pulled his hair out of his eyes in a practiced, careless movement, stepping closer towards the Prince.
"Hello," he said, tone silky.
"I am a guest staying in your fine castle, and I thought it would be amiss of me to not introduce myself.
What is your name, if you don't mind my asking?"
"Um..." The Prince fumbled, clearly thrown off by the alluring beauty before him.
Apollo's mouth ticked up in amusement; he had never managed to get this strong of a reaction from someone so handsome.
"I...m-my name is, um, Hyacinthus."
His voice was soft and rich, sweeter than anything Apollo had ever heard.
"Hyacinthus?"
Apollo moved to sit down beside him.
"That's a lovely name."
Hyacinthus glanced up at him through his bangs, golden light of the fading evening catching his eyes, and making them even more enchanting.
"...What is your name?"
Apollo opened his mouth, a lie on his tongue, but he was interrupted by a yell carrying through the garden, breaking the moment.
"Hyacinthus!"
a feminine voice cried out.
"It's time for dinner!"
"Ah, coming Leanira!"
Hyacinthus stood, brushing himself off.
He looked down at Apollo, who was still lounging against the grass, and extended a hand.
"Come with me, I can show you the way to the dining hall."
The dining hall, as it turned out, was less of a hall and more of an outdoor area protected from the sun by a roof supported by several pillars.
There were two long tables parallel to one another, where six royal children already sat.
At the head of each table were the Queen and King.
Amyclas looked up to the sound of padding feet, a smile stealing across his face when he saw the pair.
"Ah, Hyacinthus, thank you for showing our guest the way."
Amyclas turned his attention to Apollo.
"I hope he wasn't any trouble?"
It was asked in a light tone but clearly asked another, deeper question beneath it.
He didn't cause any problems, did he?
Hyacinthus looked at him, his eyes filled with fear at his answer, but Apollo just continued to smile sunnily.
"He was a splendid guide."
He waved a hand through the air, as if to brush off the notion, and Hyacinthus relaxed by his side, so subtly that no one else noticed.
They took their places at the end of the table, pulling their plates of meat and bread towards them.
Apollo smiled at him over his plate, and Hyacinthus glanced away, his cheeks filling with an appealing flush.
He believed that he was going to have a nice time here.
Part 2 Apollo stayed for a week, then two.
He explored the entirety of the gardens, strolled around the lavish halls of the palace, and visited the outer-city and the market often.
The family all warmed up to him, waving a hand when he passed them.
All of them, except for one.
Hyacinthus didn't talk to him after that night at dinner.
Whenever he saw him, his cheeks would flare pink, and he would be gone before Apollo could get a single word out.
This frustrated him, of course.
All Apollo wanted to do was just talk to Hyacinthus, that was half the reason he was still here, but it seemed like the Prince himself was intent on making sure that didn't happen.
Why did the fates hate him?
It wasn't until seventeen days, twelve hours, and twenty-two minutes after meeting Hyacinthus the first time-who was counting, though-that Apollo got his first lucky break.
He had woken early to watch the rising of Helios's chariot, dawn touching the sky with her soft pinks and oranges, when he was bumped into by the King and his youngest son.
"So sorry, sir," Amyclas said, patting him on the shoulder.
Hyacinthus averted his eyes, but bowed his head slightly in apology.
Apollo released an easy laugh, bright as golden bells.
The two of them relaxed instinctively.
"It's quite alright, my good King!
I was just enjoying this beautiful sunrise.
Although, I do wonder what the two of you are doing up so early."
His eyes caught on the cloak Hyacinthus was wearing; a traveler's garment.
"I was just seeing my son off on a journey to the surrounding city.
Some matters that need to be attended to."
The King placed a hand on the Prince's shoulder.
Hyacinthus flinched under the weight of it.
Apollo raised a single brow.
"Really?
I would've expected Argalus to be the one handling matters such as those, considering he is the heir."
"Well normally he would, but he is a bit busy currently with other, more pressing matters.
I thought I might use this as an opportunity to introduce Hyacinthus here to some of the duties of being a prince.
It's not too important that he does it correctly, anyways."
That last part was said quietly, but heard nonetheless.
Apollo looked at Hyacinthus, his features etched with embarrassment and shame, and was struck with a sudden idea.
"Well, I'm no prince, but I do come from a noble family."
This, of course, was half a lie, as the Olympians were the highest royalty there was.
"I could come with him and show him the ropes, perhaps?"
Hyacinthus looked up suddenly, eyes wide and cheeks rosy.
Amyclas didn't notice, a smile stealing across his face.
"Why, that's a wonderful idea!"
He clapped his hands together.
"As long as you don't mind?"
Apollo shook his head.
"Not at all."
Hyacinthus didn't speak to him until they were well out of the castle, buildings in sight.
The entire walk over, Apollo could feel the tension radiating off of him.
"What do you want from me?!"
Finally, Hyacinthus snapped, stopping in place along the path.
Apollo turned to face him, feigning innocence.
"Whatever do you mean?"
Hyacinthus's right eye twitched slightly.
Apollo had to bite back laughter at the reaction.
"Ever since you came here, you've been following me non-stop.
Constantly three paces behind me in the gardens, or sitting down next to me at dinner, or...this!"
Hyacinthus huffed, hands thrown up in exasperation.
"Why don't you just leave me alone already?"
Apollo smiled serenely, which seemed to make the Prince more annoyed.
He rolled his eyes, then shoved past him.
"I'm ignoring you."
Apollo threw back his head and laughed, causing Hyacinthus to speed up his pace.
"Wait, no, hold on!"
Apollo ran after him, grabbing onto the back of his cloak and checking his stride.
"Prince, wait.
I did not mean to offend.
Will you please talk to me?
I hate a silent walk, it reminds me of the numerous times my sister has been tempted to shoot me with an arrow."
A moment of silence, then a snort of laughter.
Apollo brightened with pride; he knew he was hilarious, but he enjoyed having it confirmed.
"Has she actually threatened that?"
Hyacinthus asked, amusement still evident in his tone.
He turned back slightly, a sign of surrender.
"Oh, yes, on numerous occasions."
Apollo sighed affectionately, memories of eyes as deep as the night sky glaring at him with rage that could only come from the Goddess of the Hunt herself.
"She is, frankly, terrifying."
"Hm."
Hyacinthus began walking again, slow enough that Apollo could tell he was welcome to stride alongside him, which he did gladly.
"...What's the rest of your family like?"
Apollo smiled, pleased for the attention.
"Oh, where should I even begin?"
Part 3 After that day, Hyacinthus broke down his walls, little by little.
He stopped avoiding Apollo, and often joined him on his walks in the garden.
What used to be icy stilted silence had thawed away to warm laughter and conversation as flowing as the sweet wine at dinner.
Apollo was sent with him on many diplomatic involvements, and little by little the snide remarks from Amyclas were reduced, giving way to occasional praise.
Every time it happened, Hyacinthus turned towards him, his face happily flushed, causing Apollo's nonexistent heart to stutter.
Hyacinthus became more comfortable with him physically, as well.
Often, he would place a hand on Apollo's knee while they sat out in the gardens, or a soft hug when they woke and before they went to bed.
Once, after an afternoon in the market, there was a soft press of lips to his cheek as they came up on the palace.
The next second, Hyacinthus had slipped away, Apollo still stood in dazed confusion in front of the gates.
It had been nearly three months.
Apollo could feel it in the air, that Zeus was getting annoyed with his absence.
He wouldn't be surprised if Hermes was sent looking for him soon, or at the very least Iris.
It didn't matter though; he didn't want to leave yet.
He wouldn't leave yet, not when there was still so much to learn about Hyacinthus.
A storm rolled in, a sign of his father's bad temper.
It was gone within a night, but the pounding of the rain and the crack of thunder was enough evidence that its length did not reflect its severity.
The morning after, Apollo and Hyacinthus trailed after the servants who worked in the garden, helping tend to the water-tread flowers that had sunk into the supple mud.
Just Apollo's divine nature was enough for them to recover quickly, basking in his glow.
Amyclas ran into them that night, looking terribly frazzled.
He paced up and down the hallway, muttering wildly, and barely spared the two of them a glance when they entered.
"Father, calm down, what's wrong?"
Hyacinthus walked up to him and placed a steadying hand on his forearm.
The King seemed to melt under the weight of it.
"A messenger came in from one of the surrounding farm towns a few minutes ago.
All the crops have been flooded."
He raked a hand through his graying hair.
"I don't know what to do.
Aragalus is away, the rest of your brothers are terribly busy with their studies, and I'm too old to make a journey that far.
But if I don't send someone, then this will never be sorted out, and food won't make it out to the city..."
Amyclas trailed off, looking exceedingly more worried.
Hyacinthus considered this information, tapping a finger to his cheek.
"...You could send me."
Amyclas scrunched his nose at him, a knee-jerk reaction that he schooled off his face.
"My dear son, I know you have been doing rather well recently, but this matter is really rather delicate, and you are still not the best at negotiations."
Hyacinthus huffed at the King's claim, crossing his arms.
Apollo placed a soothing hand on his shoulder.
"I would go with him, if it makes you feel any better," he said.
Amyclas looked up at him.
"Seeing as you don't really have any better options, I would like to be of some assistance."
Amclas nodded slightly, placing a hand to his mouth as his muttering started again, much less frantic this time.
"Yes...I believe that could work out well.
If you're there, then you can, yes..."
He smiled up at Apollo.
"This is wonderful!
Thank you for your help, uh, hmm..."
The King paused, a puzzled expression on his face.
"...You know, I don't believe I ever caught your name, after all this time."
Apollo smirked at him, bright and reassuring.
Amyclas blinked against the radiance that he was off putting, his face turning relaxed and his eyes glazing over.
"I never offered it," Apollo responded.
Amyclas nodded in a dazed fashion.
"I-yes, that seems perfectly reasonable-I do believe I may have overstepped-well, I mean I...I seem to have forgotten what we were talking about."
Amyclas scratched his head thoughtfully.
Apollo laughed.
"Oh, don't worry about that now.
It is getting late, however, and we need to be off in the morning.
You should go get some rest."
He bowed to Amyclas, who nodded, a little bit hesitantly, and began walking off towards his chambers.
Apollo gently pushed the space between Hyacinthus's shoulder blades, where his hand still lay.
"Come along, Prince, let me walk you to your room."
Hyacinthus looked at him with an odd expression.
Hyacinthus said, a little questioning.
Apollo brushed off the strangeness.
He was probably just a little tired.
The next morning, the three of them met in the courtyard.
Amyclas fiddled anxiously, repeating the same instructions multiple times in a row, or checking their rations even though he had already checked twice.
Apollo stroked the side of his horse's head, gently.
"Father."
Hyacinthus caught the King's hand from where it shuffled through their bags for what had to be the fifth time.
"It will be alright.
With the two of us there, what could go wrong?"
Amyclas bit his lip.
"Well, I just need to make sure that you, I mean, both of you are very competent, but..."
Amyclas trailed off, to which Hyacinthus sighed.
"Please, just put a little faith in me?
Just this once?"
Hyacinthus begged.
Amyclas stared at his son, eyebrows furrowed, before slowly nodding.
"I...yes, I can do that."
He pulled his hand away, and turned to Apollo.
"You will make sure that things run smoothly?"
"Do not fret, King.
I will make it my highest priority."
Apollo smiled at him.
Amyclas nodded again, then glanced between the two.
"Okay, yes.
Well, have a good journey, please come home by tomorrow evening."
Amyclas let out a breath, then turned towards the doors.
Hyacinthus bowed his head.
"...Good bye, my son."
The next moment, he was gone.
Hyacinthus heaved a heavy sigh, his shoulders drooping.
He looked up at Apollo and smiled, exhaustion etched into the creases of his eyes.
"Come along, companion.
It is time to begin the journey," Hyacinthus said, slinging his bag over his shoulder and pulling himself onto his horse's back.
Apollo followed suit, and soon the two of them were on the way, easy conversation flowing between the sound of hoofs hitting well packed dirt.
Somewhere on the outskirts of the city, Hyacinthus fell silent.
Apollo could sense heavy tension strung through the air.
He fumbled for a way to cut it.
"Um..." Hyacinthus turned towards him, eyes flashing in the morning light.
He looked almost ethereal.
"I've been wondering about why you and your father are so...?"
Apollo winced.
Clearly, spending time around mortals had made him lose some of his tact.
Hyacinthus turned away from him, eyes hooded.
"You don't have to tell me if you don't want to, but I just thought-" "It's alright," the Prince cut in.
"I'll tell you."
He looked up at the sky where the morning light turned from golden to sweet yellow as the day wore on.
"A few years ago, my father presented me with a potential spouse.
He was exuberant that his youngest son was engaged.
It was my job to court her, as her father had not yet decided who she would marry.
I tried as hard as I could to charm her, and I think that it would've worked out,
if..." Hyacinthus hunched his shoulders in shame.
"If I hadn't messed everything up."
He said this last part very quietly, like he didn't want Apollo to hear.
However, he heard nonetheless, his stomach twisting from the sheer pain in Hyacinthus's voice.
"Messed everything up?
How?"
Hyacinthus huffed, clenching his fists.
"I wasn't interested in her, but I figured that it was better to go along with my father's whims.
However, the night that I was supposed to ask for her father's hand in marriage, I began to feel guilty.
She was always so happy to see me, and I could not return the feeling.
I thought she might understand, so I told her my woes, hoping she would still marry me even if I did not love her."
He bit his lip.
"I still remember her running off, crying."
Apollo watched him, a crease in between his brows.
"So...then what happened?"
"I was so ashamed that I went home without even talking to the King.
My father was furious with me.
He wouldn't talk to me for months.
I might've even been thrown out if it hadn't been for my mother.
And now..." Hyacinthus broke off with a sigh.
"Well, I think you get the idea."
Apollo turned away from him, considering.
"...Once my father actually did throw me out."
Hyacinthus turned to him in shock.
"Really?
You?"
Apollo laughed at that.
"Yes, me.
He was furious with me, and he sent me to live with some farmers for a few months until he deemed it appropriate for me to return."
He smiled fondly at the memory.
"An overreaction, if you ask me, but he seemed to think it was necessary."
Apollo felt a measure of pride rush through him when a small grin stole across Hyacinthus's face.
"I just didn't really expect you to be the type who gets in trouble.
You just seem so...good."
Apollo giggled, considering how untrue that statement was.
"You would be surprised."
He sighed, a lazy smile spreading across his face.
"Although, he never tried to get me to marry."
"Oh."
Hyacitnhus stroked his fingers mindlessly over the hair of his horse's neck mindlessly.
"Why not?"
"It was never very important to him," he responded.
"Although, that doesn't mean I haven't pursued romance."
Apollo let out a breezy laugh.
Hyacinthus was silent for several moments, and when Apollo looked over, he almost looked embarrassed.
"What about you?"
Apollo saw Hyacinthus flinch at the question.
"What about me?"
"Well, I know there was that Princess, but have you ever pursued romance, just for, you know, yourself?"
Hyacinthus began to shake his head, and then stopped, face considering.
"...Kind of?"
Apollo smirked at him.
"What's that supposed to mean?"
"Well..."
He raked a hand through his hair.
"There was an event, but...it's not what you're talking about."
Apollo raised an eyebrow.
"Elaborate?"
Hyacinthus glanced up at him, licking his bottom lip.
"...You're not the first person who visited the palace recently.
Last summer, there was another nobleman, who I ended up becoming quite close to."
Apollo felt his eyes widen, his stomach twisting just barely.
"Really?"
Hyacinthus nodded.
"Yes.
I loved his company; I thought of him as my closest friend and I thought he felt similar, but one day he..."
Hyacinthus paused, swallowing, and then abruptly switching topics.
"At some point, he told me he was a god.
Zephyrus, the West Wind."
Apollo tried to suppress the scowl threatening to take over his face.
"I accepted it quickly.
It didn't make him a different person, was what I thought.
But then..." This time, when he paused, he didn't start again.
"Then?"
Apollo prompted.
"He told me was in love with me," he said this quietly, as if he couldn't bear to admit it.
"And when I couldn't return his feelings, he..."
Hyacinthus sucked in a breath.
"He was angry.
He told me that I was being selfish, and that I would never find anyone like him, because he was divine."
His fists had curled into fists, knuckles white.
"Finally, he left, but he told me that when I came to my senses, I could call upon him.
I spent the rest of that summer locked away in my room, I couldn't stand to face anyone."
"Oh, Hyacinthus," Apollo sighed, wishing he could reach out and embrace him.
"It was not your fault, you know."
Hyacinthus gave a slight nod.
"Of course he would be like this," Apollo mumbled, hoping it wouldn't be heard.
To no avail.
"What do you mean, 'he would be like this'?"
Hyacinthus narrowed his eyes at him.
Apollo fumbled for a plausible explanation.
"Oh, well, that's just what I've heard.
You know, how people talk about the Gods."
Hyacinthus furrowed his brows.
"...Right."
The air between them hung heavy and quiet for a moment, suspicion apparent in Hyacinthus' face.
Apollo felt discomfort creep through him, spreading over every inch of his body.
"Anyways, how about we talk about something more pleasant?" he finally said, if only to fill the itching silence.
Hyacinthus narrowed his eyes.
"How-how far are we from our destination?"
The heavy gaze was finally broken, the Prince looking out to the horizon.
"Still at least half a day's journey.
We'll need to stop to eat soon."
"Oh, can we stop soon?
I'm starving!"
Apollo dramatically flung a hand to his forehead.
An incredulous laugh left Hyacinthus' mouth.
"We had breakfast an hour ago!"
Apollo grinned at him.
Hyacinthus rolled his eyes, and the previous conversation was forgotten.
They reached the nearest village hours later, when the sun began to sink below the horizon.
The two were led to a small set of dingy stables on the edge of the town where they kept their horses.
Hyacinthus grinned at Apollo as they walked out, heading to the first plot of land that was affected.
They did that for the rest of the evening, going around town and asking the farmers what supplies they would need to get their growth back on track after the storm.
When they were finished, they took a stroll around, chatting amicably about nothing at all.
Apollo led them away from the actual community at some point, and into the thick forest to the west of the village.
"My mother used to take me and my siblings here all the time," Hyacinthus said as they weaved through trees.
The last of the sun's honey glow had faded, leaving nothing but the moon's silver light peeking through the leaves.
"I don't remember why, but when we had the time, we would take trips out here and stay in the forest for a day.
Back when I was still small enough to ride on the back of a cart."
Apollo considered this.
"My father never took me anywhere.
I went where I pleased, sometimes with my sister, sometimes with one of my half brothers.
My family was never close enough to all go anywhere together."
"What about your mother?"
Hyacinthus looked up at him through thick lashes.
"I was not allowed to see my birth mother often, and my step-mother, well..."
Apollo trailed off, thinking of Hera's cold sneer whenever she saw him.
"She was not exactly fond of me, being one of her husband's bastard children."
"Oh."
Hyacinthus was reduced to silence by that, eyes contemplative.
"It's alright, though," Apollo intercepted.
"I still have my siblings.
And besides, if I was not able to go where I pleased, I would never have met you."
Hyacinthus smiled at him, but he seemed quiet for the rest of the walk.
Little over five minutes later, the trees parted, giving way to clearing where the canopy broke.
The moonlight shining down on the grass made it almost look blue.
"Beautiful," Apollo breathed, stepping into the ring of trees.
"The perfect place to practice archery, or play discus."
He tapped a finger to his lips.
"Hyacinthus, do you think we could-"
He turned on his foot, a smile on his face, but it faded when he saw Hyacinthus's expression.
It was tight and confused, and a little bit hurt.
Apollo walked closer to him gingerly.
"Hyacinthus, what is wrong?"
Hyacinthus looked at him, eyes searching.
Evidently, he didn't find what he wanted, because he looked back down at the ground, a sigh on his lips.
"Hyacinthus?"
"I think I know what you are."
The statement was sudden, seemingly out of nowhere.
Apollo nearly took a step back at the conviction that overtook his features.
He swallowed.
"Really?" he asked.
Hyacinthus nodded.
"Whatever do you mean?"
"I mean..."
Hyacinthus pulled at his hair, pacing.
"There are all these things about you.
Like how you've never told anyone your name, despite being here for so long, or the stories you tell about your family, or the way..."
Hyacinthus trailed off clearly embarrassed.
"...The way you look, and how everyone treats you.
Sometimes, it seems like you change everyone's mood with a smile.
And when we discussed Zephyrus, you almost acted like you've met him."
Apollo's shoulders were drawn up to his ears, nerves flaring.
"...So, what do you think I am?"
he finally mustered up the courage to ask.
Hyacinthus clenched his eyes shut for just a second, and then looked up, surety in every inch of his features.
"You're a god, aren't you?"
Time simultaneously seemed to stop and speed up all at once, an eternity wrapped in what could only be a few seconds.
The wind quit whistling, and the trees stopped swaying.
In that instant, the world was quiet, listening.
Apollo finally broke the silence after another moment with a sigh.
"...It would be easy to deny, but it is true.
I am a god, the God Apollo."
He clenched his fists as he said it, looking to the ground in shame.
Hyacinthus nodded, resigned, then kept nodding, bracing himself against a tree.
Apollo could see in the faint silver moonlight that his eyes had become glassy.
He nearly took a step forward, to try to comfort, but thought better of it.
"Listen, Hyacinthus, I didn't mean to...
I mean, I didn't know about what Zephryus...you have to understand-" Apollo stopped when he heard a watery chuckle, then another.
He stared at Hyacinthus in shock as he dissolved into nearly hysterical laughter.
"Hyacinthus?"
"Gods, just shut up," Hyacinthus cut in, gulping for air.
There were still traces of amusement in his tone.
"You -you are just such an idiot.
I can't even believe it, you are so stupid."
In one quick movement, he pulled himself away from the bark of the tree he was leaning on, striding over to Apollo.
"What are you-"
Hyacinthus grabbed the front of his chiton, pulling him down.
His lips were soft and warm, and his hands were smooth.
They moved from Apollo's tunic to the back of his neck, pulling him closer.
Apollo felt himself wrap his own hands around Hyacinthus' waist in return, his eyes sliding shut.
His mouth was sweet under Apollo's, like long walks under the sun, and flowers in the garden.
Even under the dark blanket of the night sky, golden light poured through his body, burning away everything until there was only these few seconds.
Hyacinthus pulled away after another moment, resting his forehead against Apollo's.
There was a constellation of browns and golds in his irises.
"For the record," he breathed, "I never thought that you were here because of Zephyrus.
You don't seem like the type to do something for someone else's needs."
Apollo felt a very undignified snort escape him, to which Hyacinthus smiled.
"You would probably be right about that."
Apollo smoothed a thumb over his cheek.
"I'm far too selfish to do such a thing."
"I never said you were selfish."
"Yes but it was implied."
Hyacinthus rolled his eyes at Apollo's grin.
"You are insuffera-mmph!"
Apollo cut him off with another kiss, which he quickly melted into.
He pulled away as quickly as he came, leaving Hyacinthus dazed.
"Oh, so I'm not selfish, but I'm insufferable?"
"Apollo!"
Part 4 One month later, Apollo went back home.
It was the last thing he wanted to do, but he could tell that he was walking on the edge of his father's temper, and he needed to come back to his duties.
Olympus was darker than he remembered.
Slate gray towers curved upwards, endlessly, into the clouds.
Gold covered roofs sat high above, untouched by the light of the sun.
The gardens were beautiful, but almost soulless, contained into perfect rectangles between precisely carved marble floors and columns.
Just five months ago, Apollo believed that there was no place more stunning than Olympus.
Everything pristine and perfect, glistening in the eye of his childhood.
He could go anywhere in the world, and still he chose here.
A place fit for the greatest of Gods he used to say.
But at some point between first seeing golden brown eyes and staring into them under a starry sky, he changed his mind.
It was quiet too, lacking the bustle of servants and royal children, and the distant hum of a city.
Gods fluttered in and out, never time for more than a hello, always on the move.
It made Apollo dearly miss long walks through unkempt flowers, the feeling of soft mud under his feet, and endless conversations that led everywhere and nowhere at all.
Zeus was pleased when he came back, muttering a single phrase when he ambled back into the throne room.
"I'm glad you've remembered your duties."
Apollo simply bowed his head, walking out before another word could be spoken.
It wasn't that he had forgotten them.
From the moment he left, he knew he would have to come back home.
Truly, he had never thought it would take this long to finally return.
He wouldn't stay for long, however.
He had promised Hyacinthus, with a kiss to the temple, that he would come back to Sparta as soon as he could.
Hyacinthus had simply smiled at him, clutching Apollo's hand where it was placed on his cheek.
The memory just made him more restless to leave.
For now, though, he was confined to aimlessly wandering the vast halls of Olympus, and trying to find where all the light and music went.
Maybe, he thought, it was never there to begin with.
Days turned into weeks, weeks into months, and still everything remained lifeless.
