Are you saying you went one-on-one against the Eumenides this morning right after you went one-on-one against Achilles last night? Where does all this stamina coming from?" "My liege, I would be very glad if you would allow me to hit you just once." We are now in Rhadamanthus' palace, with the ruler of Elysium sitting on his throne and with Theseus crouched on his knees, laughing. Rhadamanthus sighed long and hard, in a way that reminded me of Hades. "What do you even do with necklaces?" Behind us, I heard Theseus choked from giggling. The judge ignored him, "I can't believe you lost yours Patroclus in less than a day. You're only meant to wear them. How could you lose something that's just hanging around your neck? And both of you at the same time?" Achilles replied wearily, "Like I've said, we took them off and they got lost in the sea." Rhadamanthus thumbed his temples, "And now you're telling me that you have also lost the sea? So you can't find the Stones?" "We didn't lose the sea. How does anyone go around misplacing the sea?" "Achilles, you have misplaced an entire river." Achilles decidedly ignored him, "This sea just pops in and out in our Elysium, you see, and it's not there now. We don't know when it will appear again." "Then why did you have to toss the Stones out to the sea?" I followed the brows that furrowed intensely on Rhadamanthus' forehead. I could tell he was really grappling to put two and two together. "We didn't toss--why do you make it sound like we intentionally--no, I actually...I might have just actually tossed..." Achilles turned at me and in that honest way he does, asked, "I did actually...didn't I?" Theseus wasn't even keeping up appearances anymore and was now laughing wildly. I tried not to get distracted and struggled to keep myself composed. "My lord," I said, humbled and apologetic. I knew full well how important it is for the Elysium to remain as a picture of perfect paradise with its residents free from suffering. "Let me--" "Us. Let us," Achilles snapped and gave me a look. I smiled. "Let us take responsibility for it. If we have to go somewhere to replace them, please let us." Rhadamanthus regarded me carefully before finally walking to the small fountain at the corner of the throne room. He picked something from underneath the pool and he closed his fist around them. He approached us and wordlessly offered his closed hand. I reached an open palm underneath them and he handed me a new pair of stones. Except that this time they did not come as a pair of necklaces. It's a pair of gleaming moon white rings that is shaped like a wishbone at the center. "It's the Rings of Hecate. Since they come as rings this time, please do not go out of your way to take them off." "Thank you," I replied politely. "They work like the stones you lost except that these ones do not rely on cheap tricks like projecting what others expect to see. It's a genuine spell of illusion." "If you have something like this, why not give this right from the start?" Achilles asked. "Because no. 1, these rings only work as a pair. On their own, it's just a piece of rock. Patroclus initially did not need it. And no. 2, these rings are not originally created as an artifact to cast the spell of illusion such as hiding the scars of Tartarus. That's just something I asked the goddess to include." "What does it originally do?" "It's supposed to be an amulet to bind your lover to you so they will not forget you especially if they are going away. According to the stories, Hecate once plucked the wishbone of an immortal bird, two pieces of bones that even if broken apart will inevitably fuse back together. Since she doesn't have a lot of immortal birds to pluck it from, eventually she made a spell that does the same thing and put them on these wishbone-shaped rings. It's apparently most effective if worn under oath on the night of a full moon. Hecate is said to preside over that oath on such a night." There was a brief silence. At least until Achilles and I broke it. I said, "We don't need this--" He said, "We don't need this --" We both looked at each other equally pleasantly surprised to know we were thinking the same thing. Then Achilles began to chuckle. I smiled. "Oh my gods," I heard Theseus groan. "Of course I know you don't need it," if Rhadamanthus could allow himself to condescend us by rolling his eyes, he would have. "It won't work on you either because you're already bound by something else stronger than that. I just find them useful when it comes to you two since those rings are also bound to each other. If you lose one of them, you can use the other to find it." "How?" "I don't know. But I don't encourage you to find out." "What if we lost both of them?" "They have the power to find their way back to whoever they belong. Those rings will only fit you and only you and cannot be worn by anyone else. But please, don't try to test that." "We won't," I declared. Rhadamanthus looked incredulous. "On the event we fail, please know that at least we tried," I said again. "Or at least, I tried." *** When we came back, the crowd in the pavilion had grown. Both the boatman Charon and the craftsman Daedalus found their way here, chatting amiably with Amphiaraus. The rest of the seven were rowdy and already drunk. Aesclepius, the greatest doctor who ever lived and died, of more renown than his father, killed by the gods for being powerful enough to raise the dead back to life, seemed--in something that felt revelatory to me--to be engrossed in a pleasant conversation with the God of Death, Thanatos. Zagreus, the Prince of the Underworld and Peneia, the unknown hidden child of Apollo were, for some reason, sulky and grumpy about something. I heard someone say, "Are you seriously grilling meat on Hestia's hearth?" To which the prince replied, "It's fine isn't it? Hestia's fire never goes out. Also, she doesn't mind." "Hold on, what are we celebrating again?" I asked Theseus. "Oh that," he gave Achilles a wreath of olives. "Do him the honor, will you?" Achilles unhesitatingly wreathed me the kotinos. I said, "What is this for?" "As the victor of the fifth game of my Pentathlon." "What? How come?" "You got Heracles on the last one so it was your victory." "What--no--that wasn't!" "It's fine, it's fine. He conceded to you already. We're holding the awarding and the banquet now." "You just want a reason to drink." "And you should too. You should always find a reason to celebrate, Patroclus. The smallest, most insignificant ones are just as worthy of celebration as the biggest, most earth-shattering of reasons. Happiness are abound in this world just as much as suffering is. Don't let any of them just pass you by unnoticed," Theseus raised me a toast and cheered. "And don't let suffering be all there is." I stared at him speechless. All this time and it is only at this moment that I am made to remember that this man had lived long enough before us, and is definitely older than us, and now also probably--gods help us all--potentially wiser than us. The evening progressed and everything felt like a whirlwind. Theseus joined those who were drinking and guzzling mead out of the amphora. Achilles and I found ourselves frying Heracles' pancakes and eating them. They were too sweet. "My throat wants to scorch itself from the sweetness of this thing," Achilles took a few swigs of the sideritis brew in between his bites. He sniped a look at Heracles and screamed at the other table, "Heracles! Why is the only thing that's sweet about you is your pancakes?" I choked in between bites and started laughing uncontrollably. Zagreus, slightly tipsy now, shouted back in reply from across the pavilion, "At least something about him is sweet! All I have is knives." "Sucks to be you Prince," Achilles yelled in response. "You won't say that if you aren't lucky enough to land Patroclus! Goddamn it. Born invincible then you fell for someone who also loved you back. That shouldn't be fair, is it?" "I worked on that brat!" "Is it that sweet?" I heard Theseus say. Heracles pushed him a plate and he took a bite. "That's about right, isn't it?" Achilles groaned. Zagreus went back to grilling by the hearth and muttered sulkily, "Yes, yes, I've got it already. No need to rub it in." Thanatos looked like he would rather be picking souls at the moment. Aesclepius came to pick one of those pancakes and gave a plate to Peneia who received them reluctantly but proceeded to eat them ravenously. "Hecate's wishbone rings," he whistled when he saw the rings decorating the fingers next to our pinky. "Mortals flock to the goddess praying for these exact rings. Depending on whoever wears them, they can either be a scourge or a gift." "Why would it be a scourge?" Achilles asked. "Wishbone rings are oath rings. And an oath you don't intend to keep is nothing but a scourge. Which makes these rings completely redundant to you since you two are already soul-bound. Why do you have these?" "As replacement for the Stones of Rhadamanthus." "What happened to the Stones?" "Please don't ask." Aesclepius stared at us and seemingly knowing what's good for him, did not pursue that question. His eyes fell on my heel. "Oh that reminds me," he stooped down and grabbed my ankle to inspect it. "Excuse me?" said Achilles as if it was his ankle that was seized. "Mmmm it grafted fully," the doctor mused. "This is nice. At this rate, you won't probably need to replace it. Double-beings sure are full of surprises. And Achilles, please don't look at me like you intend to stab me and make it look like an accident. My staff is not meant to be used that way." Achilles drove the staff with the lone snake entwined around it to the soft earth where it buried itself. "I don't intend to make it look like an accident." "Let me have a look at you too." "I don't--" The doctor seized him by the ankle too despite his protest. I watched him examine Achilles' heel and a thought occurred to me. "If you're around, would you mind teaching me?" "It's fine. His heel is fine. You won't have to worry about that. As for the gift of speed he lost, well, what is lost in River Styx can only be returned by the River Styx. Then again, being double-beings on par with the gods, why would you need it for--" "No, I mean, would you mind teaching me the healing arts?" It came both as a surprise to both the doctor and Achilles. I looked at Achilles' heel, the tendon he destroyed and I remembered how back then he couldn't even walk. I remembered the scars on his back, the wounds that caused them and the poisons that debilitated him. I remembered how helpless all of that made me feel. I remembered about those who took advantage of him when he was at his most vulnerable. I remembered and remembered, and I thought: I want to be able to do this. "Look, would you listen. Like I've been saying, why would you want to--" "Please," I said. Aesclepius sighed, "Fine. I don't mind. It's not that hard." Then he turned at Achilles, "See? That's how you get jealous. You get whoever makes you feel they are more qualified than you to teach you what makes them more qualified than you." "No, I don't think you're more qualified than me when it comes to him at least." He ignored me, "Man, I'm such a good catch it's almost a pity I already resigned myself to taking care of my brother from a different mother. Right, young Peneus?" He turned around only to find the kid serving himself grilled meat from Zagreus' batch from Hestia's hearth. "How about knowing his name for starters?" I asked. The doctor followed his young brother where he began snatching the food off his plate. Meanwhile, Achilles has stopped eating and just kept on poking the hot coals sizzling on the griddle. "May I ask why you are so guarded against Aesclepius?" "I'm not guarded against him. If we ever get into a fight--no, we can't--it would only look like I'm picking on him." "But you glare at him pretty intensely more often than you do with, say, Theseus. I'm wondering if he did something to you." Achilles was silent that I thought he must not want to talk about it. I'm ready to wait for him but he spoke again, "Because he's...he's..." he looked like he wanted to swallow the words more than spit them out. "Because he's definitely a good man," he finally said, frustrated to admit it. "Better than me in many respects that you care about. Didn't you admire Chiron because he's a healer too? So much that now you also wanted to take up the art of medicine. Back in the army, you were more known by the people you saved than the people you killed. And I'm just...just...well, I'm the opposite of that..." He continued, "Aesclepius is a doctor, the greatest in fact. He has only saved lives. He never took them. He's everything that I am not. I mean, uh, what I'm saying is..." You're saying you're jealous. Goddamn it. Seriously. I threw both palms on my face. I'll give you my soul if I have to. I'd rather burn hell than give up on you. I'd die by your hands if that will save you. And you're worried about the greatest doctor waltzing in and probably catching my eyes? "Achilles," I said, desperately struggling to keep a straight face. "You can't be this sinfully endearing all the time. It's bad for my heart and for my sense of reason." "Huh?" *** It was the darkness before dawn. Or at least what is left of it. Morning is on its way. I opened my eyes and woke up to the bodies that were strewn everywhere, either passed out drunk or just sleeping. Achilles was leaning on my shoulder. I found my hand on his. What I did not find however was the ring on his finger. I remember him going out of his way and tossing it out somewhere in the middle of the night last night while saying something along the lines of, "Let's see if your ring can really find it." It hasn't even been a full day since the ruler of Elysium specifically told us not to test it and he has already thrown it to find out. That's just one of the things I love about him. My ring felt warm on my finger. It is also blinking, dazzling and dimming alternately. I held my hand up and forward and it went slower. I held my hand to my right and there was it again, blinking fast as if telling me to hurry up. I roused myself, kissed Achilles on the forehead and followed the ring that is searching for its pair. It brought me to one of the hills in our Elysium, one of the vantage points from where you can survey the fields below and beyond. It is unsurprising to me that Achilles was able to throw that high and far. I sifted through the earth, following my ring's signal. Until finally there it was, right by the fig tree, glinting like the first rays of the sunrise that is already peeking from the horizon, dramatic reds and orange already pouring from it, bathing our Elysium. I picked up Achilles' ring. "Oh, you actually found it." I turned around, slightly surprised, "Since when?" "Since you kissed me good morning. I've been stealthily following you." The sunrise tinged his cheeks warm orange. He smiled and its warmth coursed through me. I let it soaked me in. "This here is really the best view to watch the sunrise." "Did you throw the ring out here on purpose? Is this your way of inviting me to watch it together?" "Of course not," he said, trying to be wily and shy at the same time and perfectly pulling it off. "I could just drag you out here if I want to." I gazed at him, light spilling on his face and I heard Aesclepius' words ring in my ears. Wishbone rings are oath rings. "Achilles," I said, sunrise on his face, wind on his hair. I took his hand and slid the ring up his finger. "We need no oath. We need no vows, but let me say it anyway." I kissed the hand that is wearing the ring and I declared. "Let me take care of you for the rest of our time." Here in our afterlife, afterwards, a new sun rises for us. I gaze at the rings on our fingers, fingers that are entwined with each other. I begin to think about how these rings hold our secrets with us. About how they hide the scars we share. About the soul we share. He crinkled his nose and he looked like he was struggling to keep his tears from falling. I laughed. Achilles threw his arms around me tightly and wordlessly and I embraced him back. I took him in. All of him. And we both understood. I am half of him and he is half of me. We deserve a soft afterwards my love. We were once alive and we have suffered enough. END. There will be 6 short stories titled Epilogue of the Afterwards set after this three-part series. It will be about Patroclus just being the total badass of a boyfriend he is and bringing the day of reckoning to those who deserve it. A pun on The Ship of Theseus. Achilles and Patroclus being mentors to the Prince. And Queen Perse's very wholesome flower viewing invitation over a rather almost but not quite unwholesome reason. And on that note, see you soon!To all those who have read this, thank you for your time and generosity. If you enjoyed this fic even a little bit, I would be glad.
sentences: Aesclepius and Theseus immediately followed on my heels asking what was wrong.
Confusion and panic seeped from their voices and bled with my own.
The physician saw Achilles cradled in my arms, or rather he saw the sign that gleamed under his chiton and his expression turned ghastly.
"Carry him.
Let's get out of here," he ordered.
I obeyed him.
Theseus directed us to one of the other rooms in his palace.
He stayed behind to attend to the commotion that followed.
I laid Achilles to the bed.
His face twisted in sheer pain and it broke my heart to watch him.
Cold beads of sweat formed on his forehead.
I called his name again but he won't wake up.
"Undress him," the physician instructed.
I did as I told.
I slid his chiton off him to expose the glowing rune on his chest.
Aesclepius drew the curtains close.
The rune glowed even brighter in the darkness like ember blown by the wind.
He lit a small lamp by the table and it cast light on the face of the physician.
The dread that I saw previously looked even more grim as shadows flitted menacingly on his face.
Achilles gasped and clawed on his chest as if the rune was smoldering its way through him.
The physician opened one of pouches on his belt and pulled what looked like a leather holder.
Inside were rows after rows of pins and needles.
He drew a vial with transparent liquid and dipped one of the needles about a finger long in it.
"What are you going to do?"
"Buy us time."
He stabbed the needle right through the center of the rune until its entire length buried itself inside him, pressed down by his thumb.
Achilles shuddered.
The ember glowed brightly once more then dimmed.
I jolted at the shock of having to watch all of it but soon after, the pain looked like it subsided and Achilles stopped clawing agonizingly at his chest.
However, he remained unconscious.
Pain furrowed his forehead.
Momentary relief shot through me, however, whatever was hammering loudly in my chest since the moment I realized something was wrong with him would not let up at all.
"Just what is--" "That's the unfinished Glyph of Tartarus," the physician answered, pointing at the rune on his chest.
Tartarus.
Again.
Numbness coursed through my body.
I couldn't speak.
Aesclepius sat on the chair adjacent to us, as I was kneeling down by the side of the bed, grasping Achilles hand in mine.
The physician studied me silently and said slowly, "It's also known as the Unraveling Curse."
Finally, I found my courage and my voice and asked, "What is unraveling?"
The physician looked like he thought twice before answering, "His soul."
The ground felt hollow under my feet, as if a chasm that has always been there but I didn't notice before suddenly opened up and swallowed me in.
I gripped on Achilles' hand tighter.
I can still touch him, I muttered.
He's here.
He's still here, and I'll chase him to the ends of Tartarus if I have to.
I breathed in and the lump of dread grazed my ribcage.
It hurt to speak.
It hurt to think.
I swallowed, trying to find voice from my dry throat.
Aesclepius started pacing the room, lost in thought.
The Glyph of Tartarus bore the semblance of a sundial at first glance except that once you looked at it closely, some things were strangely different.
In place of the numerals to tell the time were characters from a possibly unknown alphabet.

Unlike a sundial, it didn't have a gnomon or an indicator protruding from its center but it still cast a moving shadow around the glyph, like an invisible finger, marching and pointing at the inscrutable characters around the edge.
The glyph looked like it was supposed to be a circle except that a sliver was missing from it, like a pie with a slice taken away.

The shadow cast by an invisible gnomon ticked away on the glyph, a dark-streaked finger moving across the gleaming ember rhythmically and consistently, as if it was counting the seconds before it moves, as if it was counting time itself.
"What exactly is this curse?
This is so sudden.
He's fine all this time."
"It is not sudden and if he has it now, then he has it for a long time.
He was never fine.
He might not have just felt it because this curse, among other things, is highly insidious.
It's the kind that you'll never notice until it's..." he paused, chewed his words and spit them out, "until it's late."
"No, it is not late.
It is not.
Tell me about this curse."
"It is a rare disease of the soul.
It is so rare that it largely goes undiagnosed.
Not every physician knows about it.
To be honest, unless you're seeing it first hand, the Unraveling Curse is closer to a myth than to a disease.
Only the dead can have it and you can only get it from Tartarus.
Souls bound to Tartarus have a natural immunity against it.
In other words, only souls from Asphodel and Elysium are vulnerable to it.
And even if that's the case, it's nearly impossible to contract it from a whiff of Tartarus.
You have to stay there long enough to get it."
Aesclepius grew increasingly impatient as he explained, "Just how would he have it?
It's not contagious either.
Elysian heroes don't make a habit of going to Tartarus and staying there--"
The physician saw my face.
He understood.
"Why would he...?
No one does that.
That's madness."
"He went mad," a voice said.
It was Theseus leaning by the doorway.
He entered the room and looked at Achilles on the bed.
The sight of the curse did not seem to surprise him but his expression remained dark.
"The doors of Tartarus are forbidding," argued Aesclepius.
"Aeacus, one of the Judges and the Doorkeeper of Hades, holds the key.
You don't just walk in there for fun, curiosity, or madness!"
"He stole the keys," replied Theseus.
The physician shook his head, unconvinced, "Theseus, even Heracles himself wouldn't able to rob Aeacus of the keys.
Not because Aeacus is strong enough to overpower him but because the keys themselves will not allow anyone to open those doors except their master.

Not to mention that Zeus himself was said to have hidden those keys underneath a water forest who only allows entry to those born of the flesh of water nymph--in honor of the nymph he fell in love with, Aegina, mother of Aeacus."
Theseus exhaustedly threw himself on one of the chairs adjacent the bed.
"Doctor, the keys do not have one master.
The Doorkeepers of Hades are the Aeacidae, the House of Aeacus.

It only seems like the keys heed to only one doorkeeper, Aeacus, because unlike his sons, he alone was born of a water nymph and therefore was the only one allowed entry in the watery hiding place of the keys," Theseus paused and stared at the unconscious Achilles, his fingers locked under his chin.
It felt like an icicle dropped on my back.
I gripped even tighter on Achilles' hand that grew colder by the second.
"That man, Achilles, is born of the nymph Thetis," Theseus said, "and he's a grandson of Aeacus."
"What did you just..." "The keys recognized that he was descended from Aeacus and since he was born of a water nymph, he found where the keys were and they opened the doors of Tartarus for him.
Achilles can use the keys of the Underworld, just like his grandfather."
Silence hang heavily in the air.
Aesclepius paced the room again, more agitated than before.
"And he wasn't aware of any of that," Theseus said again.
"How come he didn't know his own line?"
"Ugh, Aeacus banished his sons alright?"
Theseus scratched his head.
"Peleus and Telamon. Wasn't a pretty story.
But that wasn't the point.

Achilles knew there were keys, and he knew he needed them to enter Tartarus, and he was determined to steal them, not knowing that of anyone who will attempt to do that, he is uniquely allowed to take it."
"And of anyone who is uniquely allowed to take it, it must be an Elysium-bound soul who went mad and stayed in Tartarus long enough to contract the curse."
"Just tell me what does this curse do," I said.
"It unravels the soul.
The unfinished Glyph of Tartarus.
It's a timer, a countdown.
What I did earlier was slow down the shadow hand
but it's impossible to stop it completely.
As long as that hand is moving, the glyph is being carved to the soul.
There's only a sliver left before it's completed."
My head was buzzing.
I strained myself to listen to him.
"And what happens when it's completed?"
"When a soul is unraveled, it will be as if it never existed."
My hands that were holding Achilles also felt cold and numb.
"What do you mean by as if he never existed?"
"He will be gone from the memories of everyone who remembers him.
He will disappear from the words of poets who immortalized him.
The Trojan War would be fought by a different warrior who would kill Hector.
The nymph who bore him would have a different son and the title of Aristos Achaion would fall on that son.
The stories of Achilles would live on but the stories would live on without him.
It would be someone else who will fill his role.
And you, Philtatos, would love someone who is not him, and no one would even know it happened.
No one would even know he happened.
No one.
Not even you.
He would be gone
but he would not be missed.
It would be as if he never stepped on the sands of time because the traces of the life he lived will be erased from it.
It's a cruel curse."
It took me apart.
My own soul grew heavy and cold in my bones.
"No...no...no, that's impossible.
There's no way that's--no way, that's just impossible.
No way.
He's dead.
We're dead.
Souls are the only ones that survive.
These are lies."
"Souls are made of the thread that Clotho spun.
Before anyone is born or have their fate drawn out for them, Clotho first spun them to existence.
Lachesis cast their lot, and then they were born according to their fate.
This thread continues to be woven until Atropos cut it and it's what survives in the end, the thread that Clotho spun.
The curse unravels what survives."
"How come we don't know anyone who had been--" I stopped myself.
Of course we don't know.
Whoever they were, those whose souls had been unraveled, their stories, their lives, we will never know.
We do not remember what we do not know, and we do not miss what we do not remember.
It is really a cruel curse.
"That's why I said unless you're seeing it first hand, the unraveling curse might as well be a myth to anyone who will hear it."
"Please tell me you can save him."
Aesclepius remained silent before muttering, "I can't."
"You can raise the dead!"
I screamed.
Tears welled up from my eyes.
"Unlike the death of the flesh, the death of the soul cannot be mended."
"No, please, please, I'm begging you," I wept.
The physician said nothing.
Grief tore through me.
I rose up and grabbed the Cloak of Alizarine.
"Where are you going?
Where do you think it will take you?"
Theseus called, grabbing my arm.
"Hopefully to Aeacus himself.
If not, Hades.
Or Rhadamanthus.
Whoever I can ask to take me to him."
"And what are you planning?"
"Ask him to open the doors of Tartarus for me."
"And what?
Get the curse yourself?"
the king read my mind.
"Have you gone mad?"
"WHAT DO YOU EXPECT ME TO BE BECOME?"
I yelled and shook his hand off me.
"Have I gone mad? 'Have I gone mad' you asked?
I HAVE!
If his soul unravels, then mine might as well do the same.
If someone else would fill in the stories he once lived, then I don't want to be in it.
I don't want to spend the rest of time in an eternity that doesn't even know him!"
Tears flow on my cheeks as my heart breaks once more in a million pieces.
And this time there's no picking them up.
This time there's no piecing them back.
Because this time there's no point.
"Weren't you happy?
In that time you spent together, weren't you happy?
Wasn't that enough?"
"If I have known about this from the start, do you think I would have been--" Then finally it dawned on me, "Don't tell me, you--have you known about this all along?"
He did not respond.
"Answer me!"
He breathed heavily and sat down once again, "We have an idea but we don't know exactly what it is.
We first saw the glyph when we picked him up after he was whipped in Tartarus.
Back then it was only about a quarter completed.
It disappeared within the day so we thought nothing of it.
The second time it appeared was when he returned after gouging both of his eyes out.
The second time lasted for weeks.
During both of those times he never fully fell unconscious like this but the pain was debilitating enough that he would pass out every now and then.
We thought it might have been a countdown of some sort because the glyph during that time has progressed to more than half completed.
Hades doesn't know about the curse but he can tell."
"What?" "That his soul is coming undone.
The god of the dead has known that the Underworld is about to lose Achilles' soul."
I cradled my head in my hands.
The dull ringing in my ears intensified to a shrill.
It cut through my temples and it was all I could do to resist the urge to crack my head open to stop it.
"And you didn't tell me."
"The god of dead did the best he could do," Aesclepius said.
"Or would you rather be miserable with the remaining time you have left together?"
The old centaur's words echoed in my head.
Do not let what you gained this day be so easily lost.
I have given up a lot in my life.
My family.
My home.
My future.
My name.
But right here, right now, lying on this bed is all I have.
I will not let anyone have him.
Not his mother.
Not his fate.
Not this curse.
"I refuse," I knelt to his side, held his hand and kissed it.
"If the greatest physician who ever lived cannot save him then I will.
If the god of the dead has given up on him, then I haven't."
"You won't even grieve over him after the curse is completed," Aesclepius said, arms crossed.
"Because you will not remember.
You will continue to live in bliss after he's gone.
However, one misstep can change all of that to eternal damnation.
Why risk it?"
I looked at him dead in the eye and said, "Because I'm a man about to lose my everything.
There's nothing I wouldn't risk."
He stared back at me silently.
The wordless air hang heavily between us and I breathed it in.
Finally, he broke his gaze and tossed his head back, whimpering.
"It's so much easier to raise the dead than this.
It's just smuggling Hades' subjects out of his realm," he griped.
"Alright.
As a physician, and as much as it humiliates me to admit, I cannot treat him.
But if you must seek divine wisdom, then you can go ask him.
He can give you answers that even the gods cannot."
"Who?" "Tiresias, the blind seer."
Another seer.
Prophecies had never treated us well.
"I don't think I have to warn you, but prophecies do not have a reputation of helping those who wanted to be saved."
"We learned that the hard way."
"Regardless, they provide uncanny insights about the future that the present wouldn't be able to conceive.
There's nothing you wouldn't risk, isn't that right?"
I gazed down at Achilles, ran my fingers through his hair now damp with sweat.
Aesclepius and Theseus left the room.
"You're right," I called.
Theseus paused by the doorway.
"It wasn't enough.
We were happy but it wasn't enough.
And if it is my fate to be remembered as that fool whose greed led to his damnation, then let it be remembered that he did so unable to let go of the only thing he refused to give up."
"I will remember," he answered and left.
I called Achilles' name over and over but he did not respond.
I remembered our days in Elysian Pelion where I did not even need to raise my voice to call him.
He would hear his name in a whisper so long as I called it.
I pressed our foreheads together, called his name once more before muttering, "I'll get you back."
I picked up Hades' cloak.
There was a waiting room attached to this bedroom and there I found Aesclepius and Theseus sitting by the table.
Heracles was also with them, a deep wound on his chest.
It no longer looked threatening but guilt tugged on me nevertheless.
"I'll buy all the time that I can so do what you need to do," said Aesclepius.
"Just come back," Heracles muttered, stern and curt.
"If he wakes up and you're not here..." "I know."
I looked at Theseus who nodded silently at me.
I draped the cloak around my shoulders and the ground felt soft under my feet.
I was no longer in Theseus' Athens.
When I looked up, gone were the lamps that lined the walls of Theseus' anteroom and the dusk streaming in from the narrow slits of the curtained window.
Instead, an empty cavernous darkness loomed over me, an infinite stretch of night, a bold absence of anything.
I looked down and yet I can see the path gleamed under my feet, the still muddiness of earth soaked in the cold dim light of the moon that was not hanging above.
For the moon was not above, the moon has sunk underneath the water, partially blotted out by the trees and reeds that gave this swamp its eerie glow.
It was curious, I thought.
The pockmarked face told me that it was indeed the moon but it told me nothing about what it was doing there.
To say 'there' was also curious for I also knew nothing about 'here', wherever 'here' is, except that 'here' feels familiar.
I have felt this brooding darkness before, the way it held its secrets and kept them close.
I looked terrible, I thought as I saw my reflection on the water.
I dropped on one knee.
My eyes were sunken and swollen.
I already looked like mourning.
It was eerily silent, or so I believe it was.
The ringing in my ears seemed to drown out everything else, even the loudest silence.
There were also flashes.
White-hot headaches that traced themselves across my skull like lightning.
Ever since Achilles collapsed in my arms, this high-pitched ringing has never stopped.
I shut my eyes tight, forcing it out of my ears.
It worked like my prayers to the gods.
It did nothing.
I opened my eyes again and there was someone--or something--staring and smiling malevolently at me from under the water.
I felt my blood curdled deep in my bones as white and bony hands shot up from the swamp and locked their fingers around my head, their nails dug on my skull as they dragged me down.
I seized those wrists and wrestled with them.
It had rows of jagged teeth, whatever 'it' was, that snapped at me and I narrowly avoided having a chunk of my face bitten off.
Then suddenly, 'it' started singing.
The song was soothing and calm that it almost lulled me to stupor.
Almost.
I clawed on those hands that were seizing my head even tighter and with all the strength I could muster, I wrenched their hold on me until I was able to yank myself free.
I fell on my back and 'it' scurried back into the swamp in a shriek of protest.
"That was impressive."
I turned around in surprise.
My body felt deathly cold.
It was one thing to look at that thing face to face.
It was another to have escaped from it.
"You were not pulled in."
A young woman with a wicker basket has been standing a few steps behind me.
She looked like she saw all of it and wasn't exactly a stranger to a scene like that.
I stood up and said, "I'm looking for the blind seer."
"That was a Stygian siren, you know."
Stygian.
I see now.
This is why this place looked familiar.
I am in the Stygian marshes.
"I see," I shrugged.
"Would you know if there's someone else residing here?
Like someone who is blind and also a seer."
"There's supposed to be no one who can resist their song.
They're peak temptress.
Infamous seducers of men."
With looks like that?
I thought but did not voice it out.
"Well, they are supposed to look irresistible to you once you hear their song," she said, reading my mind.
"I'm looking for Tiresias."
"I know," she replied.
"So how did you do it?"
I gave up and indulged her, "I couldn't hear it over the sound of my anxiety."
"That's unfortunate.
If you can look past the fact that their song will sink you to oblivion, it is music."
I clicked my tongue.
It was his laughter that is music
and I won't hear it again if I dawdle here.
The woman stubbornly kept on, "In fact there was a famous hero who wanted to listen to it so much that he asked to be tied to the mast of a ship so he won't be pulled in."
"If he wanted it so much, he should have just drowned in it."
She looked at me quizzically before saying, "But that's dangerous."
"Is it?
If you found your home in the most treacherous depths, there is nothing much worse than to be left on the shores."
"Your home is in somewhere that dangerous?"
"No.
It's my home who makes the somewhere dangerous."
"Well, he can't because he had a wife to come home to."
"Is that so?"
"More than that I'm impressed you managed to pull yourself free out of sheer will.
I was about to bring a rope."
"With respect to his wife, some of us can afford better men," I said, "Now, if can you point me to the direction of Tiresias I would be greatly thankful."
"Up," I followed her finger and there was indeed a hut on top of a small hill.
She showed the way and I trailed after her.
It was a short but muddy hike.
Each step was toe-deep.
She didn't seem to mind.
In fact she looked so used to it that she wasn't even wearing sandals.
It grew darker as we went up since we were getting further from the swamp with its sunken moon.
"Don't you have any light?"
I asked, wondering how she knew where she was going in this darkness.
"Ah, oh, hold on," she produced a lamp and lit it, as if she simply forgot and not because she didn't need it.
"Aren't you going to ask?"
"Is it far?
I don't have a lot of time."
"About the moon I mean.
What is it doing there?
Do you know whose it was?"
"Not Artemis?"
"No.
It's the chariot of the Titan goddess of the moon Selene.
It's her only chariot."
Finally, we reached the hut.
It was crude.
Despite that, it seemed to have everything it needed.
There was a rough kitchen, a tucked mattress by the wall, and an equally rough vegetable patch on the yard.
It all seemed incomprehensible to me how they grew in this gloom and darkness.
It was even more incomprehensible to me how she fared in all of this.
She put her lamp down and fumbled at her own gates.
It was curious.
You should cast the light on your gates and not on your feet.
I picked her lamp and pointed it to where her hands were.
She said thank you even if she didn't look like she really used the help.
"Selene crashed it there and lost it forever," she said again.
"She did so in order to light someone's way out even if that meant she will lose her meaning as a god.
She did it for a mortal."
Maybe if it's someone like her, my prayers would actually work.
"She stopped being a god.
Artemis took over that role," she replied, as if she divined what I just thought.
"I don't need a god.
I would worship anyone and anything who can save him," I scanned the hut and found no one else in it, "I'm going to ask one last time.
Do you know where Tiresias is?"
"Yes I do," she looked at me with eyes that reminded me of Achilles.
"And you come to me for advice."
"I am Tiresias, the blind seer," she said again at my quiet disbelief.
"I thought you're an old man."
"I am that too.
I just went with this," she twirled around, "It's nice when you have options."
My quiet disbelief turned to a quiet confusion.
"Before I was blind and before I was a seer, I was first a woman.
In fact, my becoming blind and a seer were uncanny consequences of me becoming a woman, which was in turn a consequence of, in equal proportions: curiosity, fear, and ignorance."
Our stories spoke of the prophet Tiresias as a man of few words.
I'm beginning to think that the Cloak of Alizarine might have finally broken down on me.
"But that doesn't explain why--"
"It does explain everything Philtatos.
Do you know that male snakes have spiked double penises?
I didn't know that at the time when I chanced on a mating ball of snakes.
It was a matter of curiosity at first except that they were having this steamy little tryst in the shed of some elderly woman living alone.
I feared that they would make a nest there so as much as I understood that no one really appreciates being interrupted in the middle of it, I had to drive them away.
Things went out of hand and I accidentally killed one of the female snakes."
Tiresias was well-renowned as a seer who is incapable of being wrong.
He was also well-renowned for being terse to the point of ambiguity.
I don't know about the first part, but the latter part, I'm having doubts.
"Who would have thought that the gods were given to such voyeuristic proclivities that it was an offense to have interrupted that.
I was turned to a woman as a punishment.
I tried it for seven years.
I even gave birth."
"And that made you a seer?"

"No, but it made me qualified to settle the debate among the gods as to who experience more pleasure during intercourse, men or women, as someone who has been on both sides of the bed," she continued.
"To say women is to offend Hera.
To say men is to offend Zeus."
"So you offended Hera."
"And I was struck blind.
Zeus, on the other hand, gave me the gift of prophecy."
"But that doesn't explain why are you still a woman now."
"Oh that's only because those things down there seduce every man that comes.
It's better if I stay like this."
She looked at me briefly, turned around, and picked up a piece--or rather what looked like two pieces of shawl.
She seemed to be in the middle of patching them together as there were two knitting needles at their seams and a ball of yarn trailing by the floor.
One of them was more worn-out than the other but the color and the pattern of the two pieces looked like they were cut out of the same material.
It did not look too odd to weave them together.
"Oh excuse my little art project," she said, as her hands began to work on the needles, loop after loop, the yarn went.
"I used to have a closet of epiblema but now I don't know where they all went.
They often get snagged here and there that the yarn would come loose.
Sometimes I would be too late to notice the frayed ends that I almost lost half of the material."
It was almost hypnotizing to watch her deft fingers moved through the loops and knots.
"So, do you want to ask me what the future holds for you?"
"No. I don't need to know a future I don't want to be in.
I'm here to ask how to save Achilles' soul from the Glyph of Tartarus."
She continued knitting for a while before finally asking, "What did the doctor say?"
"That he cannot cure him."
"How about the gods?"
"That it is inevitable."
"Then what is the point of trying to stop it?"
"Even so, I refused to give in to the inevitable."
"And you come to me?"
"I find my hope where I can.
Even from the depths of hell."
"How about the poets?"
"What?" "What did the poets say?"
she glanced at me.
"If the doctor and the gods cannot help you, how about the poets?"
"But what did the poets--" He is half of my soul, as the poets say.
"Want to test that?"
she looked up from her work, as if divining the words that crossed my mind.
"No, no, that's just poetry.
How could it--" "Exactly, isn't it?
It's just poetry.
At its best, poetry is only a glorified account of a past that didn't exist.
At its worst, it is a reminiscence of an unremembered truth that dares not speak itself out loud."
She studied my confusion before continuing, "A long time ago, in a story older than the gods, it was once said that humans used to be double-beings, bearing one soul in two bodies.

This 'oneness', a constitution of being whole and complete, the lack of want for anything else, a state of absolute satisfaction that defies the need for the deities, made humans powerful enough to rival the gods themselves.
Zeus feared these humans.
He feared that they would usurp power from the gods.
Therefore, he cast a curse that separated the humans between themselves, halving their power as a result.
From then on, humans will only inhabit their one body with their soul split in two.
It was said that the part of their soul where the tear was made ached so much that humans couldn't do anything else but writhe agonizingly from their lost.
Apollo took pity on them and sew these half souls on the seams where the wound was made.
The navel was the remnant of where Apollo tied the knot.
It was also the remnant of this ancient curse."
"And what happened to them?
Their other half?"
"You yearn for it.
From then on, humans learned desire.
The constant hunger for something more has never left them.
Whether it's riches, glory, or fame.
All in the hopes of filling the void their other half left.
But they never work.
Nothing truly ever did.
This perennial state of dissatisfaction, the want of the coveted unknown, the search for what makes them human, whole, and complete made them vulnerable--and vulnerability seeks the gods."
The ringing in my ears grew louder by the second.
The white-hot shrill arced across my skull.
I shut my eyes tight for a second.
"Humans can never find their other half again.
Not when they're alive.
Not even when they're dead.
To do so is a feat greater than miracles," she continued.
"The other half of your soul.
It's lost.
Like one grain of sand washed by the sea.

Humans subconsciously knew this, and have long settled with the nearest best substitute they can find, inventing ceremonies, rituals, contracts to bind themselves with, trying to become one with them, hoping to feel whole and complete again.
And even on that impossible chance you find your true half back to you, you won't know for sure.
You have long been numb from the ache."
I, for one, certainly don't feel numb from it.
I pound the base of my skull, "And how does all of this talk going to save the only soul that I care about?"
She smiled, "If he is really half of your soul, as the poets say, then the only thing that can save him from falling apart is your own soul."
"He can have it.
What do I need to do?"
She seemed briefly surprised before shaking her head, "No, not like that.
Apollo did quite a good job sewing the seams but the Unravelling Curse is more powerful than that.
It tugs on the loose ends created by Zeus' ancient curse.
To stop it, you have to close the loose ends.
In other words, you have to bind the two halves back.
If you want a chance at saving Achilles' soul, you have to reverse the curse of the king of gods."
"And how do I do that?"
"Don't you have fear?"
"On what?"
"You are risking to offend Zeus, the king of gods, for attempting to reverse his curse."
I breathed in, "I stand to lose Achilles, what else can I fear more?
If Zeus will punish me with eternal grief in Tartarus then I'd rather have that than spend an eternal bliss not knowing him.
So let me ask again, how do I do it?"
"All of this out of a mere chance of saving him?" "I'll take it."
"I understand," despite the darkness, her eyes seemed to darken even more.
"You are not the one who can do it.
However, it will be up to you if he will."
"Who?" "There's only one god who can reverse Zeus' ancient curse, Hades, ruler of the dead, god of souls."
I unfolded the cloak on my hands, "I need to know.
What happens to him if the poets are wrong?"
"You mean if your souls do not belong to the same whole?"
"Yes."
"How about you?
Are you only going to ask what happens to him?"
"At this point, I can't really care about anyone else.
So just tell me what happens to him."
"No mortal knows," she answered.
"Because that's the kind of mistake Hades wouldn't risk to make.
And he would not risk it because one: gods cannot reverse the exact same curse of each other's.
That was why even Zeus cannot reverse my blindness that Hera cursed me with.
And two: because of what will happen should he agree to help you."
My face turned white, "What?"
"Should he agree to help you, under the rage of Achilles, Hades will fall."
I froze where I stood.
Then she said next, "And I don't mean the god."
When I was alive, the realm of the dead was rarely ever called the Underworld.
The name for the realm of the dead is synonymous to the name of the god who rules it, Hades.
Therefore, should Hades agree to help me, the Underworld will fall.
But why Achilles, why would he?
"But why--" "Prophecies beg no reason, Philtatos."
I swallowed the words in my throat.
Confused, I fumbled to don the Cloak of Alizarine once more.
"One last thing," she called, now engrossed at her knitting.
"It's not always the fastest route that brings you where you need to be.
If you find yourself in a garden, then walk through it.
It might be slow, but it is not wrong."
No one really knows how to go to the palace of Hades and arrive.

This is partially owing to the fact that no one really knows the direction to go there and wholly owing to the fact that the god is not keen about uninvited guests, especially if the guests are grumbling souls of the dead who are inclined to express their dissatisfaction in a rather dramatic fashion.
Like, for example, by diverting one of the rivers of the Underworld.
Being much of a god as the rest of the pantheon, Hades would not shy away from doling out consequences as any other god would.

Except that with death, illnesses, and misfortune already out of the table, what with the dead having been there and done that, there were not just much to work with and to come up with something else equally effective would require more work than it's worth.
This is why the god would rather avoid audience except for those he provided means to do so i.e. Theseus' Lamp of Skiamati or the Cloak of Alizarine.
However, Achilles once swore that it is quite rather possible to brute force your way to finding Hades' palace if you trace any of the five rivers of the Underworld to its source.

Although, if Theseus was to be believed, that was only because Achilles cleared all the monsters that met him along the way that the naiads in the rivers simply could not stand the bloody trail he was leaving so they voluntarily led the course of the river back to the palace.
With Hades' palatial estate not being a common destination in the Underworld, it took me a while to realize what I was looking at when I arrived.
I was at the foot of a cliff and on top stood what looked like the god's palace.
A winding trail carved itself at the side of the cliff opening up to a dense forest and a muddy track.
The lush colorful shrubs and vegetation surrounded it.
I surveyed the face of the cliff and thought that while it might be difficult to scale, it was quicker and straightforward.
Meanwhile, I'm not sure where the rambling trail would lead me.
I grabbed a foothold and began climbing.
Living in Mount Pelion, I have become used to scaling cliff faces such as this.
A strong gust of wind beat my face, carrying leaves, petals and traces of varied floral scents.
The scent of a garden.
Rather than the verdant scent of lush green foliage.
If you find yourself in a garden, then walk through it.
I hesitated, then remembered.
Tiresias is a prophet who is never wrong.
I retraced my ascent, descended the cliff and headed to the trail.
True enough, I found a beautiful garden in the middle of it.
In fact, to call it beautiful is a gross understatement.
I have never seen a field of flowers quite anything like this.

There were blue, white, and red anemone and hyacinths, blue, purple, pink and white aster and bellflowers, pastel crocus, sweet pink carnations and peonies, bluish white delphinium, and white lotus and water lilies languidly drifting along the ripples on a pond.
The garden showed off its colors as if it did not belong in the shadowy glum of the Underworld.
In the middle of it stood a tree with flamboyant red flowers.
Some of it have not blossomed and remained as red buds, while others have completely grown fruits, which I found strange.
Usually the entire tree follows the same season but it seems that on this one, each flower follows a different season.
As if the entire tree is on spring, summer, autumn, and winter all at once.
It is a pomegranate tree.
"Oh?
I haven't heard of a visitor coming today."
It was the voice of woman.
She had a wreath of flowers on her head and a cart in her hands, which she was pushing in front of her.
In that cart were various garden tools such as sickle, scythe, rake, spade, shears and empty buckets.
She might be one of Hades' maids who were taking care of this beautiful garden.
"Excuse me.
I was just passing--er, no, I'm here for an audience with the god of the dead."
"I see.
This way then," she led me and I cast one final glance at the tree.
"Strange isn't it?
As if the flowers don't agree among themselves whether to bloom or not."
"Why?"
"Because it's not up to them."
She studied me for a while before continuing, "This tree is a receptacle of memories.
It takes its nourishment from the memories of anyone who will touch it.
The fuller someone's memories are, the more vibrant and flamboyant the flower becomes."
As if to show an example, she picked a stem with a red bud.
The moment her fingers touched its stem, the bud blossomed, spreading its delicate red petals in full bloom.
She smelled it briefly, smiled, and returned it to the branch she picked it from.
It magically grafted itself back to the tree.
"See?
It is grown from someone's memories.
So long as there is someone who remembers, the flower will never wither.
So long as someone remembers, the flower will never forget.
It is as eternal as the afterlife.
The flower will continue to bloom or bear fruit in a beautiful reminiscence of the memories it blossomed from."
My throat felt dry.
If I touch them, will they remember Achilles?
Will they also bloom in a beautiful reminder of him?
Or will they also wither miserably in the absence of him?
"These are mostly grown from the memories of the souls from the Fields of Asphodel," she said.
"A lot of souls condemned to forget have memories they don't want to lose.
After all, not everybody can be allowed to wander in their afterlife with their memories intact.
However, for those without a choice, this is the least we can do for them.
Whenever they see how beautiful the flower has blossomed from their memories, the more they can let it go.
They peacefully leave behind memories of their lives knowing that someone out there, in the land of the living or the dead, remembers the stories they once lived.
And that is enough for them."
But Achilles will not even have that.
There will be no one left to remember him.
I stared at the tree, grown from the memories of the dead who once lived.
It is unfair, I thought.
This is unfair.
I pinched my eyes between my thumb and index finger, I don't know, maybe because I have been struggling not to bawl my eyes out.
"Then what happens to a flower that holds memories no one no longer remembers?"
She paused and looked at me, "It disappears."
I clawed at my head.
I don't know if it was the heat behind my eyes or the buzzing in my skull that did it
but I felt tears rolled down my cheeks.
I wiped them right away.
I'm running out of time.
"Young man, you look utterly terrible."
"I'm about to lose someone very important to me and I would need the help of Hades to save him.
But I don't know if the god would even consider it."
"Don't worry.
You have my word that he will help you."
She smiled, and it was like the breath of spring, a breath of hope.
The lady accompanied me to an underground walkway where we emerged to the throne room.
The familiar, dark cloaked figure who gave me Achilles' three-hundred year receipt came into view.
Hades was not happy to see me.
"I knew one day you'll come to me about this.
Theseus should have already told you."
"He did."
"Then--" "I had been to Tiresias."
The god paused, and a disgruntled look, "That physician again is it?"
He addressed my wariness pensively, "So?
What did the blind prophet say?"
"That I only have one chance of saving him but I would need your help."
"I thought Theseus already told you.
There's nothing I can do to stop the Unraveling Curse."
I felt my hands clenched to a fist.
I couldn't bring my eyes to look at the god.
"There is.
But the prophet said," my voice strained.
I don't want to say it.
If he refused after he learned of it then I might as well have lost Achilles.
"What did he say?"
The lady from the garden was still with us.
She was standing behind me and she was still wearing the same smile she had.
I found myself disclosing the prophecy, "Tiresias also said that should you help me, the Underworld will fall under the rage of Achilles."
Silence fell.
After a while, I heard the god sigh.
He sat down on his throne, hand under his chin, he addressed me.
"No matter what Tiresias prophesized, I never intended to listen to you at all, Patroclus, much more help you.

You and Achilles have caused me enough work in the last past years than I ever had in my eternal reign as the ruler of the dead," his eyes slid past me and shifted to the lady behind me, then back at me.
"But I will listen to you, see what I can do."
I looked up at him, "You'll help me?"
"I'll have you know that personally, I wouldn't even want to listen to this.
However, you have my wife's word and I shall honor it."
Wife, he said.
Wife!
As if hit by a bolt out of the blue, I turned around and looked at the lady behind me.
"Sweet isn't he?"
Persephone beamed at me.
*** "Good for you isn't it?"
the goddess of spring said next.
"That you came by the garden.
If you walked straight to the castle's gates, he wouldn't even let you in the throne room."
"My queen," I dropped on my knee.
"That was rude of me.
Please forgive me for not recognizing you.
I am--" "Achilles' most beloved," she said.
"Yes, I know.
We all do.
Rise up.
I always wanted to meet you too.
However, not like this.
As an Elysian resident, you look far more horrible than the criminals in Phlegethon."
"I thought I have already told you before that a curse from Tartarus never heals," Hades said.
"It bows to no god and exalts no divinity.
So what did the prophet advise you that I can do?" Tiresias' words played in my head.
Because that's the kind of mistake Hades wouldn't risk to make.
I steeled myself and looked at the god in the eyes, "Reverse Zeus' ancient curse and let each half of our souls become one."
The effect was immediate.
I could almost hear Persephone stifle a gasp from behind me.
Hades froze then frowned, as if he couldn't stand the temerity I asked it with.
But at the same time, he understood.
They understood.
How undoing Zeus' old curse might save Achilles' unravelling soul.
"Madness!
This is madness!"
he stood up from his throne.
He was having none of this.
"And how would you know?
How would you know if you are really half of his soul?
The other half that Zeus has torn off since then?
No one has been able to tell.
No one!
How many do you think have thought that they found it only to realize later on that they were wrong all this time?
Finding half of your soul is like searching for a specific ripple from the sea.
You can't just tell.
What makes you think you're any different?
And no, you don't tell me it's love.
Young man, the truth is you can love anyone else just as fine even if your souls don't belong to each other."
He's right.
Of course he is.
Even I don't labor under the delusion that just because I love him, it will be enough to save him.
I have damn well loved him when we were alive but all it ever did for him was watch miserably as he fell apart from his fate.
"I have never once thought I'm any different.
You ask me how would I know.
I don't.
But love is for children, Hades.
And I'm done believing it can save anyone.
It's too kind to do something as reckless as that.
I desire him as a man, you understand.
It is not pretty and certainly not noble.
I ache for him with a desire that even if it burns Hell itself, I'd rather watch it turn to ashes than stop."
"But I don't!
And you dare say that in front of me?
The ruler of Hell itself?"
"I know
but I do.
I want him as the Greeks wanted for Troy to fall.
I want him as the soldiers wanted to rape their women.
I want him as the gods wanted to watch and do nothing about it."
Hades glared at me so fiercely it singed my skin.
I sank on my knees in front of his throne and I clasped both of his knees, an act of supplication.
I glanced up at him with all the reverence I could muster.
"I'm begging you."
The god hissed testily.
Supplicants are usually protected by Zeus which makes any king, mortal or god, wary of their response.
Except on a case like this where the supplication goes against its own protector, Zeus himself.
Hades was not looking impressed.
He rose up from his throne and shook me off.
"Why?"
I asked, still kneeling.
"So gods cannot really reverse the curse of other gods?"
"It's less of that reason," Persephone said, arms crossed.
"It's not like he can't.
If the two of you are still alive, then he can't.
The gods cannot reverse curses under the exact same circumstances the curse was given.
But since the two of you are already dead, it can be attempted.
Zeus also has less power over the dead than the living."
The god looked at his wife as if to ask why was she trying to help me.
She only smiled at him in return, a source of cheer in an otherwise glum throne room.
"Then why?
I'm begging you, please."
"Do you even know what happens if you're wrong?
If I bind two half souls that never once belonged to each other?"
"I don't."
"You will stop being human."
I stared at him silently.
"Half souls that never belonged to the same whole are vastly, vastly, different, something one cannot recklessly graft to each other at will.
If you do, the stronger between the two half-souls will feed on the other, consuming it, filling itself with what it is lacking.
It is not conscious, merely a consequence of binding half souls that are never equal, nature seeking to balance itself, until one of them loses their soul completely."
Hades continued, "Once you lose your soul, predated, you will cease to be human.
You will be resurrected as an abomination, a monster of flesh without a soul, to roam and lay waste on the land of the living and the dead.
A monster that is far worse than any of the heroes ever fought and killed."
"How about Achilles?
What would happen to him?"
"Achilles, with the blood of the gods running in his veins, being descended from Aeacus and born of Thetis, will persist.
Between the two of you, his soul is more likely the one who will remain."
"How about the Unraveling Curse?
Will it disappear?"
"I don't know.
No one has ever done this before."
"But there's a chance.
No matter how slim it is."
"Why?
Why risk it?
You understand how bad the odds are.
But why won't you get it?
You will become another monster!
Another force to reckon with!
A monster far worse than those born of Typhon and Echidna!
Far worse than the Hydra or Chimera!
Than Scylla and Charybdis!
If humans back when they were double-beings have the power to rival the gods themselves, then humans bound to the wrong half are just equally disastrous!"
I stood up from kneeling down.
"So you're saying that if this goes wrong, I will become a monster."
Hades glared.
I smiled, "Then let him be the hero in whose hands I die."
"I'm the god of souls, ruler of the dead.
Do you think I will simply allow a monster to be born from a ghost who lost its soul?
Do you think I will defile a soul this way?"
"It's my soul."
"No, no, no I can't.
That's transgression against dominion, the greatest taboo a god can commit.
A crime against myself.
It's the line I will not cross."
"The Stone of Rhadamanthus."
"What of it?" "I see that you went to great lengths to hide the scars he got from Tartarus, or the fact that he lost his eyes.
You also scrambled to have Daedalus fix him an artificial heel so he would not be permanently crippled after he cut up his heel over a stupid bet in River Styx.
Why bother?"
"What are you trying to say?"
"Why hide it?
It's not like Achilles mind if the rest of the Elysian residents know what he did.
Or perhaps you don't want them to know?"
I probed further, "You don't, do you?
You feared that everyone would find out that the Isles of the Blest is not entirely the paradisial perfection it promises itself to be.
That it is quite rather possible for someone in Elysium to spend the rest of their afterlife miserable and wanting.
And that wouldn't be good, would it?
The gods above reward and punish, and mortals live and die based on the promises of the afterlife they earned.
Wouldn't it all fall apart if suddenly they learned that all of it is not completely true?
That the promises of the afterlife can fail?
"Gods have never been truly reliable but mortals remained to devote their lives to them because they fear the consequences after they died.
And they fear it because it all seemed immutable to them.
It all felt fixed.
The unyielding will of the Heavens, the retribution of Hell.
But suddenly, there are exemptions.
I wonder how both the gods above and the mortals devoted to them would feel about that.

"If it gets known that the Underworld's Elysium can host misery and discontent, its Asphodel home to spared souls who never forgot, and the doors of Tartarus can be breached, wouldn't it speak ill to the one who rules over it?"
"I see," Hades sneered.
"And you're saying you will let them know?"
"I really would rather not."
"And you think they would believe you?"
"I don't need them to believe me, I only need them to doubt you.
Isn't faith the one thing gods need from humans?"
"Are you threatening me?"

"The glyph of Tartarus is a ticking clock.
Achilles does not have long enough left.
You know that all I need to do is detain you and wait until his time is up.
After which you won't even know he ever existed."
A knot in my heart twisted tighter.
I breathed deeply.
I brandished the Cloak of Alizarine.
It was subtle but Hades' mouth twitched, as if galled to see me unfurl the cloak he gave me in front of him.
"Detain me where?"
I asked.
"If that's where I needed to be, then I'll gladly be your prisoner.

"This is all very plucky of you, Patroclus," Persephone said, coming forward to face me.

I lost him once to his mother.
I lost him again to a prophecy.

Not to a curse like this.
This time I want to be the one who gets him.
This time I want to be the one who wins."
"And if you fail?" "Then I will fail trying."
She said nothing, or rather she seemed lost in thought.
I waited some more but she kept quiet.
Finally, it was Hades who spoke next.
"You're a changed man, Patroclus."
I scoffed, "I'm dead.
What else can I change into?"
"I actually heard a prophecy about you.
One before you arrived here.
A prophecy from one of the seven, Amphiaraus, who said that long enough you will become someone the rest of the Underworld will need to be wary of."
I shrugged, "Because of what Achilles can do when it comes to me?
Then you just need to be wary of him, not me."
"That's true if prophecies are only as honest as the first thing you think about them."

the goddess exclaimed, "Are you sure Tiresias really told you to bind your souls together?

I thought for a while, "No.

If the poets are right."

'He is half of my soul, as the poets say.'

Oh!

The answer to that is good enough that I won't sink like a rock should I need to swim.

"This is?"
I asked, knowing exactly what this is.

Under the rage of Achilles, Hades will fall, the prophecy said.

I turned at Persephone, "So how do I do this test?"
She smiled.
Hades clicked his tongue.

I kept quiet, aware of Hades' eyes on me.
