The rage of Achilles.
The fall of the Underworld.
The future where you will forget about him after this.
The future where you will stop being human and be resurrected as an abomination.
How it would enrage him, and how Hell would fall in consequence of that.
The Unraveling Curse may be gnawing its way on his soul right now and frankly, the curse might be the only way to stop him but that doesn't make him less dangerous.
His own death sentence after killing Hector did not stop him from slaughtering all those that came after him."
"And if I don't forget?" I asked.
Hades turned at me and held my eyes with a glare, calm and sinister, "And what makes you think you'll never forget?"
What makes me think I'll never forget?
I stared back at him, each word from my throat rushing in reply.
I would know him by touch alone, by smell.
I would know him blind, in madness, in death.
By the way his voice echoed in my bones, by the scars on his back, by the glint on his eyes, by the shrill in his laughter.
I would even know him by his absence, by the hollowness it leaves in my soul.
Without his memories, I'm neither dead nor alive and worse off than the damned.
But I swallowed them all and replied just as simply as he had asked.
"Because I can't help it."
I dove to the frothing pool underneath.
I might have just imagined it but the cave seemed to have shuddered right after I jumped.
It didn't take long for both the dark and the cold to sink their teeth in my skin as the waters took me in.
AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!
(See the end of the chapter for more notes.)
One of the benefits of being dead is that you have long been far removed from a very fragile and vulnerable flesh that was home to your soul your entire life.

One of the disadvantages of being dead is that you have long been far removed from a flesh that while very fragile and vulnerable is at least fragile and vulnerable enough to elicit caution and responsible use from the soul to which it was home to.
These two, of course, are not mutually exclusive and thus given to inhabit the same curve.
Achilles is simply ahead in that curve.
I immediately understood what Lethe meant by 'having the naiads brought them up'.
All the swirling and unpredictable currents beneath the surface have caused whirlpools to form.
I instinctively gasped for breath before remembering I didn't have to.
I desperately swam away from the falls and propelled myself to where the waters flowed slower.
I am determined to avoid being sucked in any of the whirlpools, keep myself in the middle lane.
After quite a while, I was able to find my head above water.
I sought where the nearest bank was, flailing my arms and kicking my legs to keep myself afloat.
A seeming endless night stretched before and behind me.
It was dim and my eyes strained to see.
I made a quick inventory of my memories.
I can still remember why I am here and who it is all for.
I am soaked enough and I have drunk enough of its waters when I took the plunge earlier.
I am not sure how does the River Lethe make one forget their memories and I don't intend to linger long enough to find out.
After scanning through the gradients of darkness, I managed to pick out a slice of dim stillness in it.
I decided it was the bank or somewhere near it and steered myself towards it.
As far as first instincts go, it immediately failed me and I headed straight to the edge of an eddy, a pool that sucked me in promptly.

I caught myself in a panic and mustered all the strength from my limbs to climb over it only to get dragged deeper and deeper until the water grew dimmer and dimmer, as if arms suddenly erupted from the riverbed and were pulling me down, the meager light from above unable to penetrate these depths.
To be honest, if I needed air to breathe, I have long fainted and drowned.
But this time it wasn't the lack of air that was to be blamed.

The water felt heavy, too heavy as if the entire weight of it were on my shoulders sinking me down further, compounded by the white-hot sharp headache that has been screaming in my skull all this time, wielding a hot blade that sliced through the meat in it with full ease.
It throbbed gently at first, a finger tap on a wooden table, then wildly the next, a battering ram across the gates.
Until finally it gave way.
Something.
I don't know.
Like a string that has finally snapped.
A latch that has been opened.
Then I was gone.
When I opened my eyes again, I was shocked to find myself underwater.
I instinctively held my breath.
It was bright and hot.
The sun was a scorching chariot high and still on the sky.
The water was clear and warm.
And salty.
Very salty.
Like the sea.
I swam upwards, wanting to rise above the surface to breathe but there was no such thing as above.
It was water all the way up.
I could see the horizon outside of the waters every time I gazed upwards but I couldn't seem to get anywhere near it. '
Have you no more memories?'
the water whispered.
Or perhaps it wasn't the water that whispered it.
Perhaps it was a voice in my head.
Or a piece of the past that has fallen of.
I shook my head, as if that would make all of the jagged pieces fall off and show me a picture, the picture.
It felt incredibly important.
It felt maddeningly urgent.
'I am made of memories', the water whispered back.
Another piece fell.
'Go.
He waits for you.'
I woke up again and the warm and bright waters were replaced by something appallingly cold and dark.
There was no sun above.
The water was a liquefied wall that not even light can pass through.
And it tastes nothing.
I was drifting right at the lip of a whirlpool, close enough to be drowned in but far enough to avoid myself from getting caught in it.
I swam frantically, the currents propelling favorably on my direction, as if it suddenly decided to help me, bringing me back to safety, to land.
I heaved myself up to the banks, drenched, every inch of me freezing.
The only thing that was piercingly hot was the sharp stabbing pain in my temples.
So deliriously scalding my brain feels like a boiling mush in my skull.
The picture.
The picture the jagged pieces are meant to form.
I reached out to the pieces.
Somewhere.
Tucked in there in the fleshy folds of my brain.
Except that the more I try to think it should be there, the more it scorches, as if razing everything down to the last piece.
Except for one final piece.
The piece that refuses to burn.
And it is a name.
The name is Achilles.
"Achilles," I muttered to myself.
It felt strangely familiar and strangely foreign.
"Achilles.
Achilles," I repeated, as if the name knows how well it rolls down my tongue.
It was all I could remember.
It was all I have.
But it felt like it was everything.
Was that my name?
No.
It didn't feel that way to me.
It felt more endearing than that.
A moment later, I was no longer alone.
Two women.
One man.
All of them not looking like they were mortals.
Divine beings.
Gods and goddesses.
They were frowning and definitely not happy.
They were silently studying me, as if waiting for me to speak first.
One of the goddess stooped to present me a branch with a lone pomegranate flower bud, motioning me to take it.
I was so confused that I didn't even bother to ask why.
I held it between my fingers.
They were looking at it expectantly.
But nothing happened.
Her face turned grim and worried.
The god clicked his tongue and spun on his heels, turning his back at us.
He mumbled some words as if issuing orders to the lingering shadows.
One of the goddesses who was wearing a translucent white tunic snorted.
I steadied myself in an effort to stand up.
Every inch of me was numb from the cold and weighed down by my clothes.
It felt heavier than it should be which seemed ironic to the searing emptiness I was feeling.
As if I dropped something in the water.
I looked back longingly at it, on the waves that rise and fall, dull in some places and surging in others.
"I have sent the seven to guard all the gates," the god said.
"Truthfully, we should more than be able to fend him off.
But the prophecy has been spoken and no matter what, it has to come to pass."
Then he turned to one of the goddesses, "You my dear will leave and go back to Olympus.
Tell Zeus that you know nothing."
"No."
"Please."
"I'm the Queen of the Underworld and if it falls, then I shall fall with it."
The ground shook violently, sending huge waves to crash to the banks, threatening to collapse the cave and bury us underneath.
A man appeared from the shadows, light flickering on his face from the lamp he was holding.
He glanced at me and I stared back at him blankly.
He looked ragged as if he went through a lot just to find his way here.
"He's here," he told the god.
The god sighed.
I want to know what's wrong.
What's happening.
Why do they all look that everything is ending?
But at the same time I am afraid to ask, for whatever it is, it seemed I had a lot to do with it.
Part of the cave had collapsed.
Chunks of rocks fell in the water.
A ray of light peeked in from the outside.
The cracks branched out further like webs until a bigger section gave way.
Something--or rather, someone limped from the hole on the wall that was punched opened, oblivious from the stones that have been falling on him.
Bloodlust lurked in those eyes, darting around the cave like a lion in search of its prey.
His gaze fell on me.
And I met those eyes.
There he was, his frame silhouetted against the light, and his eyes.
Oh.
Gleaming pools of emeralds, scandalously beautiful at the merest touch of light.
I shuddered at the sight of it.
He hobbled at my direction slowly at first, as if he couldn't believe it.
Relief soaked his face.
Then he began dashing towards me, limping and dragging his heel behind him.
It was bleeding but it did not slow him down at all.
He threw his arms around me and tackled me to the ground.
We fell together, one pair of arms securely wrapped on the other, and another pair of arms flailing on air, confused on where to put themselves.
There was another man that came after him and he looked equally battered, a huge bandage rolled around his chest.
He was inscrutably studying me, as if waiting for me to do something.
Whatever it was.
"Patroclus! Patroclus!"
the man who tackled me to the ground sobbed.
He was clasping something on his chest.
Something glowing.
It looked appallingly painful, as if it has been burning its way through him.
A circular rune of malevolent crimson.
Except that the circle has not yet fully closed itself, two lines about to touch.
Ouch.
I sucked air through my teeth.
Inside my head was a hiss.
Like something had just fizzled out.
I flinched so hard.
Something wants to form itself back but it keeps melting.
Like ice on a furnace.
"Patroclus, why?"
He saw where we were--or rather the river that I just came from.
He looked around and he saw the goddess in a translucent chiton.
Horror flushed on his face, sheer maddening horror.
His eyelids fluttered hesitatingly, the words dry in his throat.
When they came, it was dreadful and hoarse, "Lethe?
Why are you...?
This is...this is..."
He turned to me again, tears flowing on those cheeks.
"No, no, no, no," he wept and wept and wept as realization struck him.
My heart gave way with it.
"Please, please.
Don't...Don't forget me.
No, no, please."
I thought: there is nothing I'd rather remember than this man.
"I am still here!
I am still here Patroclus!
So please, please," he was crying in my arms.
"Not yet.
Don't give up on me just yet."
And then: I'd rather see Hell burn than give up on you.
Oh I see.
It's his name.
He is the picture all along.
"Achilles."
The moment I said his name this time, all the pieces fell into place.
The scorching puddle of incomprehension has been doused.
The fire that has been razing its way in my memories flickered into a wisp.
My hands remembered where to put themselves and they put themselves on his face, cupping them, wiping the tears off those cheeks.
Of course it's you.
It has been you all along.
I pulled him close, then leaned and kissed his forehead.
"Oh.
Finally," I chuckled softly.
"Now I can wipe these tears off for you."

I held up the branch of the pomegranate flower bud in my hand and watched its petals unwrap themselves in their fluttering beautiful reds, slowly and gracefully, as if it knew it had an audience to mesmerize.
Persephone gasped.
The others looked at it exhaustively decided that this shouldn't be happening.
When it has bloomed completely, I kissed it
and I tucked it on Achilles' ear.
"Yep, charming as anything," I smiled.
I looked up at Hades, "I passed.
You will honor your wife's word, won't you?"
Silence whistled in the cave.
"Please."
Achilles was confused.
He had a face that was asking what was this promise.
"It's done," the god finally said.
"That's it?"
"Yes.
Your souls are bound.
The ancient curse of the king of gods has been lifted."
"You sure we don't need to stand on ceremony for this?"
Hades sighed.
He has been sighing a lot since I met him, but this time he dragged it longer than usual.
"Pieces that fit together just fall into place.
As it should be.
It stands on no ceremonies and makes no noise."
"So what?
Have we got it right?
Oh gods.
I swear in my father's name, this is spectacular.
What are the odds?"
Persephone was genuinely amazed.
"Have we?
Are the two of them really?"
"Seems like it," Hades replied, observing me.
His terseness was inscrutable.
"Oh hold on, there is a way to check isn't it?
Apollo's knot.
Is it there?
Look, quick, is it there?"
Achilles furrowed his brow, wrinkling his handsome face, "What knot?"
I pulled on the neckline of his chiton and peered down on his midriff, wonderfully chiseled as always.
I checked mine as well.
We have both lost our navels.
We have both lost the remnant of Zeus' ancient curse.
5 Chapters without Achilles.
The dark, dark times.
In fact after Hades said 'It's done', four things began to happen at once that my own brain fumbled about what to notice first.
One: The glowing rune on Achilles' chest has disappeared.
Two: My left heel began bleeding, accompanied by a dull throbbing.
Three: My back felt itchy and slightly painful.
Four:
And oh, my left eye seemed to have lost its sight.
Which now makes me half-blind.
Might have been one of the negative side effects of Hades' curse reversal.
I did not fuss about it.
After all, it wasn't like I asked Hades for a full disclosure of the consequences.
I decided to keep mum about it.
At least for now.
Achilles would not be happy to learn about it.
Except that it didn't seem it would be willing to wait that long.
Achilles fumbled on my face, brushing his fingers on every inch of my skin, staring at me intently.
He seemed like he has been seeing me for the first time in forever--which he is.
"Oh, oh!"
he yelled in disbelief.
"I can see you Patroclus.
I can see!
It's only on my left eye though.
But I can see!"
I looked at his eyes.
One emerald.
The other was the color of warm chestnut.
I see.
I smiled to myself.
That's how it worked.
"Then you can finally stare all you want," I said, sounding casual about it.
I don't want him to know for now.
I don't want to see him beating himself over it again.
"What was it?
What have you done?
Why was I cured?
I thought the curse of Tartarus is etched on the soul?"
"Uh, oh.
I asked Tiresias about--"
"It was never cured," Hades interrupted.
"No, wait.
Please let me--" "You just shared it with him," the god mercilessly plowed on.
"You did not gain your own sight back.
That's his eye you're seeing with.
Patroclus has become half-blind."
"What?
What?" he sought me for an answer "Is that true?"
Oh dear.
"Come on, Patroclus!
Is that true?"
"It's not only that."
"Hades, please. Let me."
"Half of the scars on your back is now seared on him.
The heel you broke on River Styx has also broken his."
I watched as Achilles' face fell in shock and agony as he scanned me from head to toe.
"Your soul is no longer in danger of unraveling, Achilles.
As it is now bound to its half.
No loose threads to tug on.
However, it also means that anything your soul has incurred, whether it is a blessing or a curse will now be shared to the other.
That is how it is.
You understand?"
I sighed.
To be honest, it was no big deal to me.
I was planning to ease him into it--I mean, if I was given the chance to.
"No! Why does he have to--those were things I did!
I should be the only one who should suffer for it."
"LISTEN UP BRAT!"
Hades' voice boomed in the cave.
We all flinched and were reminded that he is a god, brother of Zeus, one of the rulers of the three realms.
Few more rocks were dislodged from the crevices due to the shock.
Achilles, laudably and silently, held the god's furious gaze.
"Would you cut it out already?
You should be thankful he's only getting away with an eye, some scars, and a heel!
He was prepared to lose much, much worse!"
Uh-oh.
He really, really didn't have to tell him that.
"Worse?
What could be worse?
What were you trying to do?" he looked at me for answer.
Hades sighed again, fingers on his temples.
"Do that somewhere," he said, shooing us away.
"If only I could exile souls, seriously I would.
I wouldn't even mind if that too-talented-for-his-own-good son of Apollo smuggle you back to the land of the living."
"Well, I am most profoundly flattered, my lord," another man with long red hair tied in a ponytail and a huge scar on his chest appeared just behind Heracles.
"But we both know that it is impossible for those whose flesh have long returned to dust.
Sadly even talents such as mine are not enough to alter the inevitable."
He then regarded me, "Thankfully you have something more than that.
Well, I'm glad you didn't meekly listen to us when we told you to give up, Patroclus."
It was a little validating to hear him say that.
It has just begun to sink in to me that I actually succeeded.
I won this time.
This time I'm the one who gets him.
"Yes.
I heard all about your little advice on visiting Tiresias," Hades shot back at Aesclepius.
"My lord, I'm a doctor.
When we can no longer save the sick, the only thing we can do is send them to someone else who might."
"Why are you here?"
"You wound me.
I'm on the lookout for collateral damages," he raised a wooden box.
"Also, I'm glad I will actually be able to affix this pair of artificial heel that I asked Daedalus to make on the off chance this little gamble succeeds."
"You mean the 'little' gamble that put the entire Underworld at stake?"
Aesclepius chuckled innocently, "To say the 'entire Underworld' is too much of an exaggeration, isn't it?
Not even a single blade of grass from Asphodel has been touched."
We blinked blankly at him.
He blinked back equally blankly at us.
Finally Heracles offered, "Apart from the castle, everywhere else is fine."
*** It turned out there was a tower on the table mountain where Hades' palatial estate was built where you can have a panoramic view of the Underworld.
Everything seems fine and as it should be.
"Patroclus," the god said calmly.
"What did you say the words of the prophet were?"
"Under the rage of Achilles..." What was it?
Tiresias did not actually say the Underworld herself, didn't she?
"Hades will fall?
And not the god, she said."
"Those were the exact words?"
"Yes."
I saw Theseus twitched from the corner of my eye and muffled his face to stifle himself from bursting out laughing.
Even Persephone turned around to hide herself from giggling.
Aesclepius feigned a cough while trying to be civil about it and Heracles remained as deadpanned Heracles.
Only Lethe and Hades remained stiffly frustrated and they were not seemed very inclined to explain to me why.
Achilles, the love of my life, gods bless him, was rather pouty and sulky about it.
"It's not like I can raze one of the three realms to ashes, Patroclus."
"Listen up Achilles.
You're wonderful and all that, but no, I wouldn't put it past you to do just that."
Theseus laughed even harder he crouched on his knees.
Finally, it was Aesclepius who deigned to enlighten me of the error of my ways.

"Well, you're a newly-minted ghost Patroclus so you aren't probably aware of this yet but I know that in the land of the living, when they say 'Hades', it means both the god and the realm he rules, but here, when the dead says 'Hades', then it means both the god and his estate, specifically the castle, the entire palatial grounds.
The dead just calls the Underworld, 'Underworld'."
"Hold on.
So when she said Hades will fall and not the god..."
"Tiresias just meant the castle will be destroyed.
Which it was."
I scrubbed my face with a very confused palm, "Why would you make a prophecy as trivial as some property being destroyed?
Castles get destroyed all the time."
"Trivial?" snapped the god testily.
"Compared to the entire realm of the dead, I mean."
"Maybe that was not the prophecy," suggested Persephone.
"I heard Tiresias has been shaking things up in the trade.
Some people say he no longer reveals prophecies in words but in nonverbal cues.
Others say that he gets you distracted with some long-winded random narrative to catch unaware whoever expects him to be gnomic.
I don't know.
Was there anything else out of place?"
If anything, everything was out of place.
First he was a woman.
Then he talked about why he was a woman.

Then there was talk about snakes, about settling a debate, all the while busying her fingers knitting two pieces of shawls together with one of them having lost most of its yarn, to make herself one whole piece of--oh.
Was that it?
Was that the metaphor all along and she wasn't actually just knitting for the sake of it?
The metaphor was the prophecy?
I clasped my knees wearily, "Oh.
Oh.
Was that it?
What the--how could I know from that?
I wasn't informed prophecies are visual nowadays."
*** We were in one of Hades' halls in his second palace, like a bunch of children brought in for questioning and scolding.

It is still unmistakably luxurious and honestly if Theseus did not tell me that this is smaller than the one Achilles wrecked because it doesn't span the length of the Underworld's largest table mountain, I wouldn't even notice.
"Even so, I can't believe you got him to agree at all," Theseus said.
"No. It was only because the Queen helped me."
"To go as far as reversing the curse of Zeus himself..."
The more I looked back on it now, the more I think how impossible it has all been.
From beyond a thick double-lidded door, slightly ajar, voices drifted.
One was disgruntled.
Stately and remorseful.
It was Hades, "That man.
First he begged.
Then he threatened."
Followed by a voice I knew full well.
Shamelessly unapologetic and divinely pleasant, "Let me apologize for that.
Bedroom habits die hard--" I burst in the throne room, throwing the heavily-lidded doors out of the way as if they were paper, "Oi!"
"It's funny you still get embarrassed over this," Theseus whistled at my heels.
"You should be.
It's not like you want your mother to know."
"Hades is not our mother."
"No, that's not the point.
"Then what is?"
"Ugh."
"I will work on it as well," Heracles stepped forward, distracting us.
"After all I'm half the reason of the wreckage."
"Because you just have to stop me," Achilles grunted.
"I wouldn't even dream of it.
I was merely stalling you."
"Did the two of them really..." I mumbled.
"Well, yeah," Theseus muttered back.
"You could imagine how it was.
Tremors were felt everywhere in the Underworld.
It wasn't that hard to believe that the end is nigh.
Which is weird because this here is the end.
So it's like the end of the end is nigh."
"So does everybody, uh, know..."
"No one said anything of course that it was Achilles who was marching madly to Hades."
"Oh good.
That's--" "Because they already knew it was him.
I mean, the odds of any devastating rumble that threatens the Underworld that is not caused by him is slim to nil.
As anyone who has been dead long enough would tell you, 'it got so livelier in the last three hundred years'."
"I will build as many castles as you want," Achilles was saying.
"Though I must say I have only ever built our pavilion."
"His works of art though are something only Patroclus would love," interjected Theseus.
"Yes, and no heckling," I shushed.
"Deny it a little would you?"
"Obviously I wouldn't leave it to you," the god said to the two of them.
"I'm trying to build a castle not win a war.
Fine then.
You'll be pardoned in exchange of your labor."
"I might not be worth much but I'll help," I volunteered.
And a strange thing happened.
I was half-expecting Hades to mock my offer or dismiss it entirely.
But he looked at me all business-like, seriously considering it.
"You may be right," he said finally.
"I could use one with a reliable pair of hands and a reasonable head on him without a whiny mouth attached."
"Hey!" that was Achilles.
"Hey!" that was Theseus.
The two of them looked at each other in chorus.
"What?
Why are you protesting as well?"
Achilles spoke first.
"Obviously, I'll have Patroclus work in my Athens.
He owes me a lot after that stunt he did with Heracles."
Oh.
I almost forgot about that.
I awkwardly swiveled a head to glimpse at Heracles.
He saw me peeking at him but he remained coolly indifferent about it.
I bet being struck by a spear through the chest hardly bothers the greatest hero of all time
but I bet it also never happened before.
"And why would he need to work for you?
Why would he owe you?"
I could see a nerve or two popped on Theseus' head, "Have you seriously forgot the room you thrashed?"
Oh.
Achilles hissed, "I would make you a new bed in all kinds of olive tree you want.
Does that make you happy?"
"And who do you think paid for all the bets placed in the last game?
He will pay your share too."
"Then I will work for you too.
That should be fine isn't it?"
"Why are you, ugh, have you known you?
You're a pain in--gods know where.
Last time you prepped the grounds for the Pentathlon, you made me listen to all the nasty details when you made Patroclus your--hmmm!"
Achilles muted Theseus with his right hand on his mouth and with his left hand, he grabbed Heracles beside him by the elbow and shoved him in between them.
"Then take him!"
he declared.
"Patroclus and I are good enough to build a castle or two."
I could almost hear Heracles' unflinching indifference shattering to broken pieces of bewilderment from where I stood.

And to those who may have previously thought, "Where's the M in this work?

But as Patroclus would like to say, it's pretty hard to make out when your partner is under the threat of total non-existence so he must first figure that one out.

We were back in Elysian Pelion.
Back home again.
With him.
His mood has considerably improved.
It still stung him to have the follies wrought by his unauthorized jaunts to Tartarus shared to me.
I kept reassuring him
I didn't mind it all.
It didn't work.
I told him that it was a cheap bargain in exchange for his soul.
It also didn't work.
I convinced him that it hardly hindered me at all.
It was hardly convincing.

In the end, I have to lean to his cheek, intentionally brush my lips on that sensitive skin behind his ear, and whispered in a very low, smitten voice, "It ignites me to see something of mine in you all the time I can't stand it."
I don't think I'm far gone to resort to something like dirty talk in broad daylight when it comes to matters I'd rather resolve lucidly but it seems weirdly effective.
It has been a while.
I was expecting Pat to come barking at us in welcome
but he did not.
For half a second I was worried he might have died of starvation until we found him wagging his tail frenetically to someone who appeared to be waiting for us in the pavilion.
It was Rhadamanthus, ruler of Elysium, son of Zeus, and brother of Minos and Sarpedon.
The same Sarpedon who died on my hands.
It was always awkward to meet him but he has never shown me any grudges for anything we did back when we were alive.
Here, in the Underworld, he is only one of the three judges, weighing the merits of souls as he sees them.
"It's about time you arrive," he said, weary and stern.
He handed me a dark velvet pouch.
I peered inside.
"You need to wear one yourself."
It is another Stone.
"Um, uh, thank you," I replied, not really knowing what else to say.
Rhadamanthus panned his eyes from me to Achilles.
"You really now have the same shared soul."
Somehow the way both he and Hades looked at us made me wonder if we now appear differently to them.
There was always that curious squint, that double pause as if they were confirming who they've got.
I would have wanted to pry more out of Hades but it felt like it would have cost us more than a castle if I did.
"Uh, will there be any adverse repercussions?"
I asked.
"You mean other than your eye, some scars and your broken heel?"
"No. I mean genuinely adverse repercussions."
"You mean the kind that are adverse only to Achilles?"
"No," Achilles cut in, his voice could bend steel.
"He means aside from his eye, the scars, and the broken heel."
"I don't know.
Hades does not bind souls for a hobby.
So, except maybe for a few obvious things."
"Like what?"
"As already demonstrated, both blessings and curses are shared.
Your soul is entangled to the other, and it's the kind that makes distance irrelevant.
You are half of each other's soul, and now it's not only for the poets to say.
It will be for anyone who sees it to say, gods and mortals alike.
You share a bond as ancient as the gods.
If there's anyone who should know what is that like, why don't you tell me?"
We looked at each other, confused but satisfied.
"But..." Gods, can they not, for the love of their wretched omniscience be putting calculated 'buts' or 'what-ifs' at the end of their good news?
If it wasn't all that good from the start then don't let us soar on empty hopes then watch us fall flat on our backs.
"Philtatos, you remember why Zeus split humans from their halves in the first place, don't you?"
"Because humans as double-beings are a threat to the gods, is that the one?"
"Yes."
I wrinkled my nose, confused and waiting more from him.
It did not come.
"And then?" I prompted, helpfully.
Achilles shrugged, "So what?
I have always been a threat to anyone, the living, the dead, gods, mortals.
What changed?"
Gods, that cheek in that mouth of his.
And I love him for it.
"Yes, and that's you Achilles," Rhadamanthus replied.
"Nothing much might have changed for you.
But we are yet to see what it is for your half."
It was all baffling but I have had a lot to deal with recently.
Achilles is here with me and nothing else matters.
"Let's not keep you then," we politely saw him off.
*** It was late afternoon in our Elysium.
I don't know how long we were gone but it did not seem like we had any unwelcomed visitors.
No visible harpies perched among the trees.
"Oh it is back," Achilles exclaimed.
The beach of sprawling fine white sand, the glittering sea rolled out before our view, extending out to the horizon, emptying to gods know where here in the Underworld.
Despite what Achilles may say about his mother, he could never truly hide his excitement whenever the sea appears.
It's always on his face, like a paint that refused to be peeled off, that childish delight, that sort of vague reminiscence of his youth.
He ran towards the beach.

I kept my eyes peeled on him, even if only one of them can see him, it has no problem watching, taking in the sight of him so intently that I could almost feel the wind that brushed his hair, the taste of salt on his skin.
This is what I would be missing if I gave up, and suddenly it hurt.
My stomach squeezed inside me at the mere of thought of it.
It was hard and scary and it all felt too hopeless, but Achilles is here and
oh.
He's here and it is all worth it.
He's here and it's everything.
My knees buckled under me and before I knew it, I was crying I almost couldn't believe it.
As if all the pent-up emotions I dammed up inside because I don't have the time to go through them just swelled and broke through all my defenses.
All of it.
My insecurities, my fears, the pain of losing him again--all of it just bubbled in my chest, begging to be felt.
Suddenly my tears were pouring on my cheeks and spilling on the sand.
I'm glad.
I'm so thankful I did not let him go.
I don't care how many things I gave up when I was alive, slipping through my fingers as if I never deserve any of them, my mother, my father, my name, my home, my future.
But this time--this one time when it matters, this one time when it meant the world to me, I'm so glad I hold on to it.
And I will keep holding on to it, no matter what it cost me.
"Patroclus!
The water feels good!
Let's--WHAT'S WRONG?"
he came running to me, his face dissolving into panic as he saw me crying.
"Something is wrong after all?" his voice trembled.
"No, no, no," I touched his arm, smiling, reassuring him.
"I'm fine.
Nothing is wrong.
I'm just really, really relieved.
It's all just coming to me now.
I was on the verge of losing you again--and that's--" Oh gods, I really couldn't stop crying.
"That's really terrifying," I sobbed.
"The idea of not being able to see you again, even as a ghost...I can't stand it."
Achilles wrapped his arms around my head, pulling me close to his chest.
I could smell the sea on him.
"I'm sorry...
I'm sorry...
It was all because of me," he kissed my hair, my forehead, the corner of my eyes, as if to soothe me.
"I'm here now.
I'm here.
You brought me back to you."
I returned his embrace, burying myself into him, yes, yes, just like this tall wave which is about to bury us in three...two--uh.
The tide surged and fell, crashing into us and drenching us both.
We both fell into laughter.
To be honest, I would rather us be back in the cave right now, back to its warmth, our bed lying just under the stars.
That's what I would rather.

But Achilles is now dripping wet in front of me, the fabric of his chiton sticking on his skin, showing what lies underneath, the smooth lines of his sinews, then there is that supple neck of his and those shoulders attached to it, those well-sculpted collarbones just underneath, the protrusion on his throat that I know how to tease out of him, and all the things I can do with them.
I would rather us back in the cave right now.
But here he is in my arms, a beauty like no other, criminally perfect, endlessly endearing.
And there's pretty much nothing I can do about it.
I pulled him by the back of his head and I squeezed our mouths together, which is as inelegant as it sounds, but nothing about what I feel right now is even remotely elegant.
I slipped him the tongue
and he just melted.
He returned my kisses, twisting his tongue this way and that, in that way he knows best, which is rough and ravishing.
"I want you," I gasped, dazed.
He chuckled, "I heard you the first time."
His fingers are all over me and my lips are all over him.
I can feel his fingertips on my scalp, combing through my hair.
I am at his throat, right beneath the chiseled curve of his jaw, gliding my lips through it, kissing his neck, the length of his shoulders which readily flush red at the merest graze.
He stares at me.
He has been staring at me a lot.
Then I remember that until a while ago he cannot see.
I only didn't feel that much difference because he put the work to make it seem that nothing changed.

He did all of it so I can continue to be with the Achilles in my memories, the unblemished, invincible Aristos Achaion, and not the one who cannot walk without an artificial tendon attached to him, not the one with all those whip scars on him, and definitely not the one who cannot even see the man he has been waiting all this time.
"I miss seeing this look on you," he whispered.
"What look?"
"The look that says how much you want me.
I have been trying to imagine it all this time."
"Then go on and take a long hard look...at the face of a man who is drowning with desire for you."
We felt so heady and floaty that I don't think I'll be able to recount even with a cool head how we found ourselves drifting in the sea.
I was beneath the water when I went down on him.
My hands on his hips, his hands on my head.
I let my hands wander around him.
That dip on his waist, the shallow grooves by the side of his abdomen, that part of his stomach where his navel had been.
The inside of his thighs.
Since I cannot see his face, I can only tell how I am doing by the way his fingers run themselves on my head, or the way his body curls or the way his hips slowly thrust.
I want to feel him.
I want to feel him when he peaks.
But just before that, I am yanked off the water by the two hands on my head, and kissed--kissed as if all the kisses we had before were never enough.
I kiss him back, two bodies sharing the same soul bobbing up and down with the tides.
Slight annoyance darts on his face as the water stubbornly insists on disrupting us.
He brings his hands on my shoulders, and we both dive down and deep, so now we are both underneath the waves where the currents are calmer and more steady.
We are a tangle of limbs.
I lock my arms around him and his arms go over my shoulders and around my neck.
We do not care about where we are or how deep we have been swimming.
We cannot see anything else but each other.
One soul that has been aching for its half for as long as it can remember.
One soul that is filling itself whole.
One soul that finally feels complete.
We come out to the surface gasping not for air but for each other.
The sand is soft and comfortable.
We crawl back up to the beach, him sitting on that space between my folded knees while I sit cross-legged, his back turned at me.
We are both wearing the Stone of Rhadamanthus so we remain blind to the reminders of Tartarus.
I lick his nape, alternating between biting and kissing.
His hair dripping beads of water on his shoulders did nothing but only make them more enticing.
He clasps my forearm, unable to tangle his fingers in any of the fingers from both of my hands because they are both busy pinching and kneading other places.
I fondle him with one hand, with the other around his thigh, his body pressed against mine.
I can feel his heat, his pleasure, as he arcs and twitches, his sweetest moans skipping him.
"Pa...Patroclus...I'm..." I twirled his face towards me by his chin and mumbled, drawing a breath so close to his lips he trembled, "Then come for me Achilles."
I sealed his lips as he spilled himself in my hand.
"Just me again," he complained.
"You really don't have to do this," I said, as I watched him peering at me from between my legs.
"Wow, who is saying that?" he grinned.
"I have been feeling this grinding at my back since earlier."
He puts on his cat smile and keeps his eyes fixed on me, a pair of royally elegant emerald and warm melted chestnut.
I helplessly throw a hand over my face.
Oh his fluttering eyes and his pretty little mouth and all the things he does with them.
"Hnghh momnning hnor fmes..."
"Please do one thing at a time Achilles."
"No covering your face."
Then he added, "Especially now that I can see it."
I did as I was told and watch him.
I could feel the air caught in my lungs.
My toes curl and bury themselves underneath the sand, painfully aware of how good the fine grains felt on my skin, painfully aware of how good it all felt.
He fixed me with a gaze that held me where I sat.
He pins my knees on my side, with him wedged between them.
I look at him and I gulp down at the sight of him.
I swallowed hard and he looks like he wants to follow my throat down my neck.
I cradle his cheek with a palm, and he nuzzles with it.
I groan.
I am not there yet.
He did not bring me there.
He knows what he is doing, pushing me right to the edge, just close enough to fall without having to jump.
My eyes caught a table of shale carved not too far from us, waves crashing beneath it.
Smooth layered claystone, wide and circular, punctured with holes in places that are filled by water.
It looks perfect to me.
"Hey!" he protested as I dragged him along.
Until he saw where I was bringing him.
"Oh sweetheart.
Should I worry on what you intend to do to me there?"
"No such thing.
But you should at least be prepared to beg."
I throw him above it and he lies flat on his back.
I followed him and climbed on top of the stone as well.
"Strip," he ordered, high and mighty.
He sees how hard I was.
He giggles.
"Who's going to beg now?"
"Tease."
I slung his leg over my shoulder and I suck at the skin by his thigh, bruising it carefully, one after another, an inch after inch closer.
He watches me as I go through all the motions of it.
He keeps his mouth behind the back of his hand, stifling all the noises that comes from it.
Then he reaches out for my hand with his free hand and brings it in his mouth, licking the fingers on it, his tongue darting in and out of each them, wetting them one by one.
Sometimes when I caught myself in that space between solid clarity and high-strung madness, I almost cannot bring myself to believe we can be like this, that we can be allowed to be like this.
This would be unimaginable when we were alive.
Sunset at the beach.
The waves crashing beneath us.
Right under the open sky, in the middle of the open sea.

As if we are compensating on that time we were on a beach and just his lips brushing against mine sent us scurrying away out of fear that his mother might see, that the gods might see, or that anyone might see.
But him right here with me, a trembling heap of pleasured mess.
There is almost something unspeakably transgressive about it and all of that only makes the blood pound louder in my ears.
I push a finger in and he yelps slightly.
I twist his body to his side.
I can reach in deeper this way.
He tenses, as if bracing himself.
Then the second finger in, up to the second knuckle, then the third.
"I want you without the Stone," I said.
To be honest, he never really needed to hide those scars from me.
It does nothing to how much I desire him.
But this is something I don't ask of him often because I know it still bothers him and also because I don't want to remind him of what he had been through before I arrived.
I kiss his hand, "You know how I want you just the same."
He hesitates but nods, "Only if you also remove yours."
I slid it off my neck.
He tugged at his own necklace swiftly and surely, then carelessly chucked it somewhere.
"How about revenge?"
he offers his wrists to me, pressed to each other as if bound.
I suck the air through my gritted teeth.
He laughs.
I am a taut string.
He knows it and he relishes tugging at me harder.
I indulge him and I bind his hands with the string of my necklace, the Stone dangling from it.
I pin those wrists with a single hand over his head.
I look at him and I savor the image of him like this.
The stretch of muscles that wrap themselves around his ribs, drawn out tighter with his arms above his head.
The tough and flexible sinews behind his upper arm, tensing and flexing at each movement.
He props himself slightly and hoops his bound arms around my head and pulls me down and close, his lips brushing my ear, both of his legs hooking themselves below my hips.
Now it is his turn to kiss the scars on my body.
"Show me how you want me," he whispered.
I glided my hands underneath, lifting his chiton with it.
My touch leaks the moans from his throat.
I bore down on him, my body pressed on him, our hips grinding at each other.
He dug at the skin on my back, cutting our teeth on pleasure we are learning from each other's body, as if what we had all this time was never enough.
My thumb seared against his temples, sweat and water mixed, I cradled his head between my hands and brought his lips to mine, tucking his body in.
I hemmed and sawed.
To say I drank him in will never be enough.
I want him the way Tantalus wants to drink water, the way he wants to taste that fruit.
Except that unlike Tantalus, I can drink my water and taste the fruit
and I will still be left in wanting.
We felt the strength left our bodies, satiated, two half-souls who finally found each other.
You know what they say.
