"So, uh," Persephone tapped a polished finger on the table.
"Just asking.
I mean, I know it's too late to do anything about it, but, uh, you're not that mad are you?"
"About what?"
Hades answered her across one of their suite of rooms.
Where is this?
In Hades' second palace?
"When I saw Patroclus wandering in my garden looking every bit of a lost soul, I know I want to help him.
I don't regret it and I still wouldn't regret it even if, you know, even if he didn't succeed," she said.
"And I know I shouldn't be saying something like that as the Queen of the Underworld.
To lose your realm on behalf of one ghost is unthinkable.
But I look at Patroclus and I can hear Orpheus' head bobbing on the Island of Lesbos, still singing of his love for Eurydice, still mourning of her lost.
It haunts me until now.
And I just don't want to see something like that again."
Is this a dream?
Are you supposed to know it's a dream when you're in one?
Hades' eyes fell on the lone potted pomegranate plant by the corner of the room, a rather odd detail on the overall decoration, then to the taller vases beside it as if studying their paint.
More like he couldn't bring himself to look at her.
Even after all this time if he stares at her long enough, he gets a funny feeling in the pit of his stomach.
He loves his wife dearly.
That, he knows.
Though he doubts if she does.
Not with the way he claimed her.
She is the goddess of spring, the goddess of hope, someone who prizes beauty in impermanence, someone who'd rather burn beautifully very briefly than live in gloom for eternity.
A complete opposite of him.
That's also what he loves about her.
She's someone he shouldn't be allowed to keep by his side.
But she's here.
And if she says she wants to burn Hell itself for the sake of one soul, then she very might as well do and he will watch it burn with her.
"I am sorry too about Orpheus," he said, finally.
"I tried what I can.
But that was all the chance the laws of the gods could give him."
"I know."
"And I'm not that mad because I was never mad to begin with."
"That's not true."
"It is," he replied simply but firmly.
"Those two really are just...exhausting.
Then there's them with their souls restored to each other and what that meant.
We're prepared for Achilles.
We've seen the things he did and we know the things he can do.
Achilles is a drawn out sword that you can see coming, but Patroclus...that's the thing.
He's a sword too but you won't know that until his blade is already under your rib."
"So this is what it means on having both curses and blessings shared?"
Hades nodded, "He is now every bit of a warrior as Achilles.
To say the Underworld now have a pair of Aristos Achaion wouldn't be wrong."
"That sounds fun."
"Extremely," Hades tried to smile to indulge his wife but he really couldn't pull the corner of his lip high enough.

"Achilles is an invincible half-god to begin with and now with Zeus' curse undone, they also reverted back as double-beings, which is something the king of gods himself feared, powerful enough to rival us should they wish to.
And I doubt they even realize any of that."
"Hmm, Patroclus?" the goddess paused, tilting her head.
"He's pretty much done thinking after the glyph of Tartarus disappeared on Achilles.
And um, Achilles...nope...
he's always been powerful and all that.
I don't think he does a lot on any of those things: notice, realize or think.
Impulse drives him and that pretty much sums up his life and afterlife."
I was gliding through the hall, peering at a room.
I feel like I keep hearing something important that I will forget later on.

Hades pinched that space on his forehead between his brows, "They are Hell's most problematic power couple to be honest and just the thought of having to babysit them for the rest of time is already making me tired."
"You worry too much dear."
"I think I should.
One of them already altered the landscape of Hell as he pleased, flouted the rules, breached Tartarus, and destroyed a castle.
While the other wouldn't even bat an eye in razing it all down for the sake of one soul--and all of that, back then when they were still something not akin to a god."
"But all of that, back then, were because they were threatened to lose the other.
If anything, you should worry less about it now because their souls have been bound."
Then she added, rather unnecessarily, "I bet right now they are melting into each other's heat they couldn't even think about anything else, much less the things you were worrying about."
"Uh, I really don't need to be reminded of that."
"What do you mean?
It's beautiful.
I'm planning to invite them over for a flower viewing and have them tell me all about it.
I bet they can't refuse me.
I'm their top patron."
This is also one of the things he loves about her.
Now that she mentioned about flower viewing, Hades said, "I've been meaning to ask, but what's up with the potted pomegranate?"
"Oh," Persephone seemed to have forgotten about the plant either.
"This is what has become of the flower Patroclus grew."
"That?" "Yes."
"I thought you grafted the flower back to the tree of memories?"
"I did."
"And isn't it supposed to stay there as one of the flowers in eternal bloom?"
Persephone crouched down and started poking the potted plant's small pomegranates.
"We don't know what it's supposed to," she said.
"We just know that the flowers in that tree tend to stay there in eternal bloom--until this one didn't.
The flower Patroclus grew bore a fruit which fell from the tree and before I realized it, it became like this.
This needs to be replanted to give it a wider berth."
"It's still growing?"
"I think it is.

Unlike the others in the tree which were grown from the memories of the dead in Asphodel, this one is growing from 'living' memories, I mean, memories that are still being made and shared between the two of them."
"But Patroclus just grew that flower."
"Well, since they're half of each other now..."
"Oh, so Achilles' memories are growing that too."
"Yep!"
she chirped.
"Lovely isn't it?
I'm thinking of giving this to them so they can replant it in their Elysium
and--oh I know!"
"What?"
"Since you're too worried about what they would do..." "That's because anything that happens to either of them, the Underworld also has to get involved."
"Exactly.
So I'll plant this in my own garden."
"And how would that...?" "Like I've said, this pomegranate is growing from their memories, the memories they made before, the memories they are still making, and the memories they are about to make.
In other words, the health of this pomegranate will tell us whatever is happening between the two of them that you should or should not worry about."
"Hold on Perse, that sounds, uh, quite rather the Elysian privacy-breaching surveillance.
I'm not sure if it's lawful for us to--" "No," she said, determined.
"I think we have a duty to keep the rest of the Underworld safer from their potential future antics.
I call this an early warning threat detection tree."
"Alright," Hades responded, smiling a little and not doubting a single word his wife said.
"It is what you said it is."
I open my eyes, wide-awake now, I feel like I've had just some incredible dream and listened in to an equally incredible conversation.
I cannot remember any of it except that they feel important and that they are currently slipping through my very muddled brain which is having a hard time to even tell up from down.
So, first things first, I have to make a proper inventory of events, and probably establish our location, find where is north, extrapolate from it.
Glean the position of the sun on the sky, the length of the shadows, whatever.
Except that I wasn't able to do anything much beyond open my eyes and feel drunk.
Intoxicated.
Haze weighs on my head far more heavily than any alcohol has ever done.
Ah yes, this, and this, and that.
I can remember yesterday's sunset.
And the sea.
Definitely there was a sea.
That much I am sure of.
Beyond that, I cannot tell, for the love of all things holy, where did both the sea and the rest of the night go.
It was already morning.
And we were lying, or rather leaning to this massive and magnificent cedar tree that I never even knew we had in the middle of the pasture land of our Elysium.
All our sheep, goats, and cows have already gone on the business of taking care of themselves because we have obviously very well failed them.
They have been grazing and roaming and we have been sleeping, the Cloak of Alizarine acting as our blanket because our clothes cannot be bothered at the moment.
I saw a flash on the midday sky--no, I did not actually see it.
Rather, I sensed it was there.
No, it wasn't actually there yet.
Rather, I sensed it would be there in a short while.
Like something ominous has been stalking us in the horizon.
I very quickly slung my chiton around me.
I dressed Achilles, careful not to wake him, tucked him under the cloak, and kissed him by the forehead.
Then I ran towards our pavilion, to the shed that houses our kitchen supplies, gardening tools, as well as Achilles' bows and spears.
I grabbed one of his spears.
I cannot tell exactly what I am feeling threatened by or where exactly is that feeling coming from and why.
I can only sense it
and I just know.
Like how some animals twitch their keen noses at the slightest whiff of danger.
Or in my case, like how I stood in the middle of the field, eyes scouring the skies, Achilles' spear ready in my hand.
Then it came.
A glint of something.
Like the tip of a blade.
It darted unhesitatingly right where I stood.
It did not merely drop from the sky but was very pointedly shot down.
It was not thrown broadly.
It has a target and it reached it--me.

I might have screamed in alarm should I have the space for that but in that moment, all I could see was the tip of the blade, how it was perfectly aimed at me and my hand twirled the spear, its bladed end connected to it, dulled its speed, and sent the sword pirouetting back up in midair.
It was a xiphos, a double-edged, one-hand shortsword.

A malignant sneer almost crept up on my face when I realized that someone found it in themselves to threaten us with a 'secondary' weapon, something short enough that it demands a skilled close quarter combat and one-handed enough that its owner seems confident it can brace against anything using only the strength of their one arm.
Which, as I would soon find out, is exactly the case.
Someone caught the xiphos I tossed spinning in the air by the hilt and expertly rammed it downwards against me.
I held the spear with both hands above my head so the blade of the xiphos fell at its center, and not--as it originally intended--on my head.
I also managed to see what it was exactly that I was dealing with.

What it was, was a pale-skinned young woman with a deathly cold glare on her eyes, wearing mourner's robes and sandals, and who also feels strangely familiar to me that I begin to believe I should know her.
However, remembering was not at all made easier if you are fending for yourself while in the middle of it.
She was, to say the least, extremely skilled in fighting as if she does this very professionally for a job.
I, on the other hand, have not done anything that vaguely resembles anything warrior-like, either as a hobby or a job in life or in death.
At times like this, when faced with insurmountable forces, mortals tend to pray to the gods above for help.
However, being a ghost in the Underworld, that severely limited my choices.
Then again, it's not like it would have made any difference if one is still alive, at least it did not work that way for me.

After all the only reason I did not lose my life that early in the war was not because some god were protecting me but because Achilles was there, always keeping an eye out for me, preemptively shooting men to their deaths before they even came close.
He's the one that works for me, I thought.
More than any god, I'd rather speak of his name and call it a prayer.

I remember that time he let me watch him secretly practicing with the spear, how he mentioned he does not let anyone else watch him fight, and how at first I did not understand why, until I saw how he fights then I knew.
He fights like a warrior blessed by the gods that no ordinary mortal could ever come close to, no matter how much they work hard they would have to live with it.
As one of those ordinary mortals, I lived with it.
The gods have always been fickle and unfair, favoring some while cursing others, but if it's him they favored, I don't mind.

I think back on all the times I watched him fight, how his lithe figure would wield the spear, how his swift-footedness would have doomed anyone before they even realized it, and how I have his own spear in my hand right now.
A lightweight and perfectly well-balanced double-ended spear: a thrusting pike on one end and a slicing double-edged blade on the other.
My body has been moving on its own, not having any spare second to pause and reflect on what it is doing or what to do next.
I was merely replaying how Achilles fights in my memories and was hit by a damning realization that I really don't know how to fight any other way except his way.
There is no one I have watched more than him and therefore I can only fight like him.
Fighting half-blind has further sunk in me just how impressive Achilles has been, going toe to toe against Heracles himself, while being completely blind.
Then again, a fight like that requires you to react faster than you can see and he has always been terrifyingly adept with that.
I, on the other hand, for the lack of choice, have been trying.
Despite being blindsided on my left, I could quite sense where the next one is coming.
And I don't think being able to see fully would have helped anyway because by then it would be too late.
She is terrifyingly quick, as if her feet do not even touch the ground.
She is extremely clever too.
She keeps jabbing the xiphos right on my chest, where it is the hardest to defend with a long weapon.
I evaded all of her attempts by always sidestepping to the side and keeping myself at spear-length.

She still manages to sneak in through all that so I can only spar against her with the middle section of the spear that I have been holding with both my hands, which also tends to be trickier than holding a sword with a hilt.
At least you know where to put your hand if you have a weapon with a hilt.
Wielding a spear means adjusting your hands along its entire length as situation demands.
She is also brutally efficient with her movements, not letting up at all, the tail of her robes fluttering sharply behind him.
She is raining her offense that all I could hear is the blunt thud of her blade against the shaft of my spear and the sharp thrill when it hit the bladed end.
I rallied as her blade falls, defending more than attacking.
Then her blade pressed firmly on the shaft of my spear, forcing a battle of power, her sword inching closer on my face.
I held my ground and pushed, pushed, and pushed back, until she peeled her sword away as I drove her backwards.
I huffed, "Would you mind--?"
But I was wrong.
She did not step back because she withdrew.
She did so she could lunge herself anew towards me, using the distance to gain momentum.
I clicked my tongue.
Seriously.
I braced myself.
Just when I thought I knew how her blade is going to fall, it changed course.
Of course it was all but a ruse on her end.
I should have known.
Instead of attacking from above or center, she dropped on her leg and swiped the sword from under me.
I saw this before.
But back then it was done to Achilles and I'm no Achilles.
I sighed and in those terrifying few seconds I have, I remembered hard what he did.
I straightened my back.
I'm not going to let anything ruin what we gained this far.

In that split second before she dropped on her leg to swing the sword by my legs, I ran up towards her and thrust the pointed end of the spear to the ground and like a vertical pole I used it to vault myself above her head.
She looked like she expected me to do exactly that, which is probably rule no. 1 on the things not to do during battles: getting predicted by the opponent.
She spun on her heel just as quickly, her blade already waiting on where I was about to land.
Shifting position mid-air is pretty much an impossible maneuver given the lack of anything to anchor yourself with, unless you have wings, which I don't.

Or, unless of course you time it well enough, and nimble reflexes are something you don't think of very much like water to a fish, then you can land to the shaft of the exact blade that has been trying to impale you on the exact moment it appeared there--and use that as a springboard for your previously impossible mid-air maneuver and somersault the hell out to safety, which was exactly what I did.
Oh Achilles, I thought.
How you made it all look too easy.
Thankfully, I was able to land on my feet few paces away from her.
Thankfully, she also finally ceased her torrential assault.
She looked at me seeming contented.
I tried again, "Sorry, but would you mind--?"
Then the ground shook.
It was as unmistakable as anything, I felt bloodlust shot up right from behind me.
He is here.
Achilles lunged from above wielding another one of his spears pointed towards our dark-robed visitor.
The pointed end connected and she caught it right at the middle of her blade, defending against all the power that spear was thrust with only one hand.
Achilles spun and sparred, this time becoming the one on unrelenting offense.
Each strike he made connected and it shook the ground.
This time she was not even bothering to return any of his attack.
Like me from earlier, she was just defending.
This increasingly irritated Achilles and decided to throw one fatal thrust at her and I have a bad feeling about it.
"Achilles--wait--" I called.
"CALM DOWN!"
someone screamed, unflinchingly wedging himself between the blades of a spear and a sword with nothing but his body and sheer unadulterated grit.
And this time it is someone I don't have a problem recognizing.
That was a writing workout.
Actiony stuffs.
A fight scene right after an erotic scene.
I honestly don't have lots of verb exercise as someone who mainly ever lives off sedentary nonfictional explainy stuff lol "No, you calm down," followed another voice, for there were two of them.
It was smooth like honey and subdued like poisoned.
"And what, in my name, do you think you're doing?"
"Whoa.
You actually called it on your name.
You're pretty mad aren't you?"
the plucky boy gasped in mock surprise, his arms outstretched in utter mad hope that it would stop the two blades from clashing.

Of course it wouldn't and it didn't and he should have been impaled very thoroughly a second ago had it not been for this other boy standing behind him who pulled him by the shoulder and with his other hand stopped Achilles' spear, neatly stopping the iron-tipped pike between his two fingers.
As if stopping blades throttling down in full power and speed in the nick of time with only his fingers is something he does very professionally for a job.
Achilles hissed but withdrew.
The dark-robed woman sheathed her xiphos and stepped back too.
Her eyes darted between Achilles and me, squinting really hard at us, as if her perfectly sharp pair of eyes suddenly began failing her.
She looked very confused but she seemed very willing to shrug it off if it meant she could get out here faster.
She seemed like she would really mind tarrying any longer than this.
In fact, she already looked like she would rather do something else than talk to us.
She announced, "The Aristos Achaion passed.
I see to it that he is qualified to the become your mentor."
Huh?!
Now there are a lot of things to be surprised about what she said.
Like, for instance, who passed what, what did he pass, and who is going to be a mentor of whom.

But what is more surprising than any of that is the fact that she doesn't seem to know who is the Aristos Achaion she meant to be talking about because she has been decidedly looking at me while undecidedly glancing at Achilles.
Then with a spark of finality and idle compromise, her eyes settled on me.
The boy asked, "You mean Achilles?"
"Yes, him," she pointed at me.
"At least that's the one I tested.
And gods have mercy on you if you make me test this other one.
I have work."
"That's Patroclus.
This other one is Achilles."
She grunted, still squinting at the two of us, "Nope.
Looks the same to me."
"I guess primordial gods cannot really tell," he then turned to the other boy who previously saved him, "Actually, how could you?"
"I can't either, but Hades said there's a trick to being able to tell them apart.
If it feels like it's likely to attack you, that's Achilles.
But if it feels like a perfectly calm river that you shouldn't be crossing, that's Patroclus."
"Is it?"
the dark-robed woman said musingly, looking at us.
"Hmm.
That seems like it."
"I really can't tell how souls must look at you two," said the boy.
"We don't look at them," said the other boy.
"Yes.
It's more like we sense them," replied the woman.
"Sorry, can I get word in?"
I let my impatience got to me.
"First off, I have no idea who might you all be.
And secondly, what is this talk about not being able to tell us apart."
"Oh that.
Well, primordial gods like these two can only see--or sense souls since that's what they deal with mostly.
Anything living in their mortal flesh is not their business yet," the boy explained, as if primordial gods only seeing souls is the dreariest thing he ever said.
"With the two of you having the same soul, as in soul-bound and all, you now look exactly the same to them.
And that's true the older the god is.
Younger gods and those born with mortals in their lineage can pretty much tell you apart.
Those who made it their job to rule over souls and judge them might have to pause and squint a bit to be able to tell."
He paused and seemed to have remembered, "Oh, and to answer your first question, the one here who tested you is Megaera."
Oh.
I feel like the inside of my stomach lurched.
I know that name.
She regarded us fiercely and coldly.
The boy laughed the sudden heavy atmosphere that fell on us, "One of the Erinyes, goddess of--hold on, what do you punish again?"
"Infidelity?
Cheaters, liars, breakers of marriage vows--and look, I know what you're thinking: with the countless broken marriage vows with married men and women sleeping with whoever, am I even doing my job?
And the answer to that is--yes because that actually is not my job.
They only use my name to scare their spouses from cheating.
Because believe me, if that actually is my real job..." an almost devilish grin flitted on her lips.
"Zeus won't even have a second chance to try again.
And with that, I'm going to leave.
My real job is waiting for me."
She left as quickly as she arrived, a blur of shadow that flashed on the sky.
"She's a childhood friend, the warrior of us all.
Fighting her is courting disaster," the boy shrugged, in that way you do when you tell someone they have just courted disaster.

"Then this one here is Thanatos, the God of Death, a job he actively hates, and also my best friend, a strenuous relationship I have been trying so hard to change into something that will make me his boyfriend--" "Seriously?" said the god.
"With no success thus far," the boy cheerily continued, blatantly ignoring him.
"As I remain to be dumped for as long as I can remember.

As a result, I'm looking to spend the rest of eternity in a bittersweet unrequited love to my best friend which in turn, will make me the Underworld's most eligible bachelor, unless of course I can make him change his mind."
Then he added, in afterthought, "Oh, and I'm Zagreus by the way, son of Hades and Persephone, which probably makes me the prince.
Nice to meet you."

Just when I thought I could recognize them as those two boys back in Theseus' Elysian Athens during the Pentathlon, the ones who helped me retrieve Hades' cloak after it was accidentally 'misappropriated' over gambling reasons, the one with an odd pair of eyes, one green and red, and the one with him dressed in pure black, they turned out to be significantly more than I can simply recognize.
One is a pureblood offspring of the gods while the other is a primordial god as old as time.
"Do you think we could have used some warning in advance?
Being attacked out of nowhere is a bit..."
"I heard you were supposed to be informed about it."

As if on cue, we noticed the rising columns of smoke coming out from the pavilion, indicating that someone else has just invited themselves over without permission, and indicating that it might be someone we know full well.
*** "Oh hi there, finally you show up.
We're here to celebrate first thing in the morning.
I can't believe we can't get ahold of you.
Also, I can't believe I'm the one serving your guests.
By the way, we used your kitchen," he said not even looking at us, both of his hands occupied with bowls filled with spiced uncooked meat.

"Oh yeah, one of the sisters, the goddess versatile on all weapons she could effectively slice through anything even with the dullest knife, known under the fake title of the 'Jealous One' and also the prince's stand-in mentor is coming for Achilles to test--oh."
He then turned around and finally saw us, with both the prince mentioned and the best friend he's in love with in tow.
That was of course Theseus who uses the place like it is an extension of his palace in Elysian Athens.
"So she already came?" he said as his eyes briefly fell on us, his attention divided over a million other things in the kitchen.
"Is this fine?
Tastes bland to me," for some reason, even Heracles was there fiddling with a bowl of batter.
"Might be lacking something.
Heracles, if you mess up something as simple as these pancakes, I'll be too embarrassed to accept your bride's dowry.
Don't think you're hotshot just because--hmpf!"
Heracles just poked a finger with the batter in Theseus' mouth.
"Then tell me what's lacking."
"Honey."
"Yes?"
"Honey, I said."
"What?"
"Or what, you don't want this sweet?"
"Oh I do.
I very much do."
"Then get on with it."
"I have been all this time."
A voice from the outside, "Your Highness, the hot coals are about to go out.
Are you not even using this to grill anything?"
Theseus cursed under his breath, "My gods, I forgot.
Wait!
Skewer this first and grill them!"
And just like that, he shuffled out of our sight from the kitchen and Achilles followed him.
The prince and his best friend trailed after him as well which leaves me alone with Heracles who was now pouring copious amounts of our honey to his batter.
"Sorry, what's happening?"
"He wants to throw a banquet," he said.
"But figured the two of you might not want to go to his Athens, so he brought all of these here."
"Uh, and since when have you been here?"
"This morning.
You're not coming down from the mountain and you're not in the pavilion either.
He waited for like, a blink or two, before deciding to start grilling."
"And those outside?" "Umm?
The seven?
They have been drinking since they arrived."
"Drinking?"
"Yes."
"Like tea?"
"No, like wine."
I dashed outside.
"I. Am.
Not.
Drinking," Achilles spelled it out for me when he saw me slightly frantic, raising a plate of fig pie to me, occupying a space on one of the long tables.
I scanned our pavilion, and for some reason, it felt...uh, full and busy.
"Oh nice," Zagreus said, immediately pulling himself up by the hearth.
Thanatos sat down beside him.
"The hearth is blessed.
Hestia likes this place very much."

The god of death looked around the hustle and bustle around the pavilion, to the dead who have not even noticed him yet, to the dead who have been drinking both wine and tea this morning, eating pickled olives and fig pies.
Something deliriously similar to a smile almost flickered on his face.
"No.
It's because this place is like this that Hestia blessed their hearth.
Not the other way round."
"Come on.
If you cannot love me at least don't antagonize me."
The god of death groaned, "Must you always remind me?"
"How else would l I know if you already changed your mind."
Outside the pavilion, hot coals glowed on the ceramic trays where the skewered meat will be grilled.
Theseus and his retinue brought these portable grill as well as the griddles from where I believe Heracles would cook his pancakes.
There were several of these smoking grills and griddles arranged in a semicircle and being tended to by the seven, who were also getting drunk while on it, except for Amphiaraus who was sipping tea.

It felt strange, for some reason, to have Heracles back in our kitchen making pancakes, Theseus and his band of seven grilling skewered meat in front of our pavilion, and the Prince of the Underworld and the God of Death huddled up in the corner by our hearth.
If a prophet ever told me when I was alive that in the afterlife, this is what I would be having, I would not believe it.
All of this felt kind of wrong to me somehow.
But then, I see Achilles munching down on a fig pie I made for him, crumbs on his cheeks and suddenly everything feels right.
I smiled and thought to myself, yes, this is how it is supposed to be.
"WHAT?!"
Theseus exclaimed.
Gods, what is it this time.
"What do you mean the Eumenides came and fought Patroclus?
Also, why didn't I see it?
I wanted to watch it.
Why didn't you call me?"
Oi.
What do you mean you want to watch?
Is this all an entertainment to you?
I met Theseus' eyes and just when I wanted to make a run for it, he caught me by the arm and fussed about it, "You!
You...did you?"
"He did," Tydeus, one of the seven, said.
"We saw the whole thing from up here.
It was entertaining."
"What?!"
now it's my turn to scream.
"You watched the whole thing--and you just watched the whole thing?"
"That's one of the Eumenides you know.
You don't make a point of crossing her."
"Having a fight like that to watch made the wine better."
"We called you, you know," said the other to Theseus.
"Didn't you even notice the earthquakes just now?"
"Achilles fought too," said the other.
"Hence, the earthquakes.
Seriously what were you even doing with Heracles you didn't notice?"
"And then?"
Theseus asked.
"And then what?"
"I'm asking how did the judgment go?"
"She just said the Aristos Achaion passed.
Although she seemed confused as to whether she meant Achilles or me."
"Ah, oh, yes, of course," he replied, unsurprised.
"But what are you doing taking on one of the sisters?
First, you swam Lethe.
Now you crossed with one of the venerable goddesses?
Just where all this daring coming from?"
"Because no one told us that she is scheduled to drop in today and Achilles should have been ready for that."
"How am I supposed to tell you that if I cannot even find you?
Rhadamanthus said he just gave you the Stone yesterday, so where were you actually--hold on, where are the Stones?"
It's the season for banquet.
(See the end of the chapter for more notes.)
Theseus, gods bless him, would not stop laughing.
And I feel like I've seen him like this before.
"Where are the stones?" he asked.
I looked at Achilles.
It was not around his neck.
I fumbled around my chest and mine was not there either.
My very muddled mind tried its best to sort out its memories of last night.
The last time I saw them was when--oh.
"Hey, what's with that look?
Don't tell me you lost them?
Then start looking for them already.
Achilles is one thing.
But how did you lose yours too Patroclus--" Theseus' eyes alighted on Achilles who was putting another bite in his mouth.
I followed what he was looking at, curious as to why he stopped mid-sentence.
He was looking at his wrists, or rather, the string marks that were left on them.
I threw a palm on my forehead.
"Oh forget it," Theseus grinned at me.
"I know exactly how you lost yours."
Then he paused and frowned, as if something piqued his curiosity once more, before muttering softly, "Patroclus, you.
Are you saying you went one-on-one against the Eumenides this morning right after you went one-on-one against Achilles last night?
Where does all this stamina coming from?"
"My liege, I would be very glad if you would allow me to hit you just once."
We are now in Rhadamanthus' palace, with the ruler of Elysium sitting on his throne and with Theseus crouched on his knees, laughing.
Rhadamanthus sighed long and hard, in a way that reminded me of Hades.
"What do you even do with necklaces?"
Behind us, I heard Theseus choked from giggling.
The judge ignored him, "I can't believe you lost yours Patroclus in less than a day.
You're only meant to wear them.
How could you lose something that's just hanging around your neck?
And both of you at the same time?"
Achilles replied wearily, "Like I've said, we took them off and they got lost in the sea."
Rhadamanthus thumbed his temples, "And now you're telling me that you have also lost the sea?
So you can't find the Stones?"
"We didn't lose the sea.
How does anyone go around misplacing the sea?"
"Achilles, you have misplaced an entire river."
Achilles decidedly ignored him, "This sea just pops in and out in our Elysium, you see, and it's not there now.
We don't know when it will appear again."
"Then why did you have to toss the Stones out to the sea?"
I followed the brows that furrowed intensely on Rhadamanthus' forehead.
I could tell he was really grappling to put two and two together.
"We didn't toss--why do you make it sound like we intentionally--no, I actually...
I might have just actually tossed..."
Achilles turned at me and in that honest way he does, asked, "I did actually...
didn't
Theseus wasn't even keeping up appearances anymore and was now laughing wildly.
I tried not to get distracted and struggled to keep myself composed.
"My lord," I said, humbled and apologetic.
I knew full well how important it is for the Elysium to remain as a picture of perfect paradise with its residents free from suffering.
"Let me--" "Us.
Let us," Achilles snapped and gave me a look.
I smiled.
"Let us take responsibility for it.
If we have to go somewhere to replace them, please let us."
Rhadamanthus regarded me carefully before finally walking to the small fountain at the corner of the throne room.
He picked something from underneath the pool and he closed his fist around them.
He approached us and wordlessly offered his closed hand.
I reached an open palm underneath them and he handed me a new pair of stones.
Except that this time they did not come as a pair of necklaces.
It's a pair of gleaming moon white rings that is shaped like a wishbone at the center.
"It's the Rings of Hecate.
Since they come as rings this time, please do not go out of your way to take them off."
"Thank you," I replied politely.
"They work like the stones you lost except that these ones do not rely on cheap tricks like projecting what others expect to see.
It's a genuine spell of illusion."
"If you have something like this, why not give this right from the start?"
Achilles asked.
"Because no. 1, these rings only work as a pair.
On their own, it's just a piece of rock.
Patroclus initially did not need it.
And no. 2, these rings are not originally created as an artifact to cast the spell of illusion such as hiding the scars of Tartarus.
That's just something I asked the goddess to include."
"What does it originally do?"
"It's supposed to be an amulet to bind your lover to you so they will not forget you especially if they are going away.
According to the stories, Hecate once plucked the wishbone of an immortal bird, two pieces of bones that even if broken apart will inevitably fuse back together.
Since she doesn't have a lot of immortal birds to pluck it from, eventually she made a spell that does the same thing and put them on these wishbone-shaped rings.
It's apparently most effective if worn under oath on the night of a full moon.
Hecate is said to preside over that oath on such a night."
There was a brief silence.
At least until Achilles
and I broke it.
I said, "We don't need this--" He said, "We don't need this --" We both looked at each other equally pleasantly surprised to know we were thinking the same thing.
Then Achilles began to chuckle.
I smiled.
"Oh my gods," I heard Theseus groan.
"Of course I know you don't need it," if Rhadamanthus could allow himself to condescend us by rolling his eyes, he would have.
"It won't work on you either because you're already bound by something else stronger than that.
I just find them useful when it comes to you two since those rings are also bound to each other.
If you lose one of them, you can use the other to find it."
"How?"
"I don't know.
But I don't encourage you to find out."
"What if we lost both of them?"
"They have the power to find their way back to whoever they belong.
Those rings will only fit you and only you and cannot be worn by anyone else.
But please, don't try to test that."
"We won't," I declared.
Rhadamanthus looked incredulous.
"On the event we fail, please know that at least we tried," I said again.
"Or at least, I tried."
When we came back, the crowd in the pavilion had grown.
Both the boatman Charon and the craftsman Daedalus found their way here, chatting amiably with Amphiaraus.
The rest of the seven were rowdy and already drunk.

Aesclepius, the greatest doctor who ever lived and died, of more renown than his father, killed by the gods for being powerful enough to raise the dead back to life, seemed--in something that felt revelatory to me--to be engrossed in a pleasant conversation with the God of Death, Thanatos.
Zagreus, the Prince of the Underworld and Peneia, the unknown hidden child of Apollo were, for some reason, sulky and grumpy about something.
I heard someone say, "Are you seriously grilling meat on Hestia's hearth?"
To which the prince replied, "It's fine isn't it?
Hestia's fire never goes out.
Also, she doesn't mind."
"Hold on, what are we celebrating again?"
I asked Theseus.
"Oh that," he gave Achilles a wreath of olives.
"Do him the honor, will you?"
Achilles unhesitatingly wreathed me the kotinos.
I said, "What is this for?"
"As the victor of the fifth game of my Pentathlon."
"What? How come?"
"You got Heracles on the last one so it was your victory."
"What--no--that wasn't!"
"It's fine, it's fine.
He conceded to you already.
We're holding the awarding and the banquet now."
"You just want a reason to drink."
"And you should too.
You should always find a reason to celebrate, Patroclus.
The smallest, most insignificant ones are just as worthy of celebration as the biggest, most earth-shattering of reasons.
Happiness are abound in this world just as much as suffering is.
Don't let any of them just pass you by unnoticed," Theseus raised me a toast and cheered.
"And don't let suffering be all there is."
I stared at him speechless.

All this time and it is only at this moment that I am made to remember that this man had lived long enough before us, and is definitely older than us, and now also probably--gods help us all--potentially wiser than us.
The evening progressed and everything felt like a whirlwind.
Theseus joined those who were drinking and guzzling mead out of the amphora.
Achilles and I found ourselves frying Heracles' pancakes and eating them.
They were too sweet.
"My throat wants to scorch itself from the sweetness of this thing," Achilles took a few swigs of the sideritis brew in between his bites.
He sniped a look at Heracles and screamed at the other table, "Heracles!
Why is the only thing that's sweet about you is your pancakes?"
I choked in between bites and started laughing uncontrollably.
Zagreus, slightly tipsy now, shouted back in reply from across the pavilion, "At least something about him is sweet!
All I have is knives."
"Sucks to be you Prince," Achilles yelled in response.
"You won't say that if you aren't lucky enough to land Patroclus!
Goddamn it.
Born invincible then you fell for someone who also loved you back.
That shouldn't be fair, is it?"
"I worked on that brat!"
"Is it that sweet?"
I heard Theseus say.
Heracles pushed him a plate and he took a bite.
"That's about right, isn't it?"
Achilles groaned.
Zagreus went back to grilling by the hearth and muttered sulkily, "Yes, yes, I've got it already.
No need to rub it in."
Thanatos looked like he would rather be picking souls at the moment.
Aesclepius came to pick one of those pancakes and gave a plate to Peneia who received them reluctantly but proceeded to eat them ravenously.
"Hecate's wishbone rings," he whistled when he saw the rings decorating the fingers next to our pinky.
"Mortals flock to the goddess praying for these exact rings.
Depending on whoever wears them, they can either be a scourge or a gift."
"Why would it be a scourge?"
Achilles asked.
"Wishbone rings are oath rings.
And an oath you don't intend to keep is nothing but a scourge.
Which makes these rings completely redundant to you since you two are already soul-bound.
Why do you have these?"
"As replacement for the Stones of Rhadamanthus."
"What happened to the Stones?"
"Please don't ask."
Aesclepius stared at us and seemingly knowing what's good for him, did not pursue that question.
His eyes fell on my heel.
"Oh that reminds me," he stooped down and grabbed my ankle to inspect it.
"Excuse me?" said Achilles as if it was his ankle that was seized.
"Mmmm it grafted fully," the doctor mused.
"This is nice.
At this rate, you won't probably need to replace it.
Double-beings sure are full of surprises.
And Achilles, please don't look at me like you intend to stab me and make it look like an accident.
My staff is not meant to be used that way."
Achilles drove the staff with the lone snake entwined around it to the soft earth where it buried itself.
"I don't intend to make it look like an accident."
"Let me have a look at you too."
"I don't--"
The doctor seized him by the ankle too despite his protest.
I watched him examine Achilles' heel and a thought occurred to me.
"If you're around, would you mind teaching me?"
"It's fine.
His heel is fine.
You won't have to worry about that.
As for the gift of speed he lost, well, what is lost in River Styx can only be returned by the River Styx.
Then again, being double-beings on par with the gods, why would you need it for--" "No, I mean, would you mind teaching me the healing arts?"
It came both as a surprise to both the doctor and Achilles.
I looked at Achilles' heel, the tendon he destroyed and I remembered how back then he couldn't even walk.
I remembered the scars on his back, the wounds that caused them and the poisons that debilitated him.
I remembered how helpless all of that made me feel.
I remembered about those who took advantage of him when he was at his most vulnerable.
I remembered and remembered, and I thought: I want to be able to do this.
"Look, would you listen.
Like I've been saying, why would you want to--" "Please," I said.
Aesclepius sighed, "Fine.
I don't mind.
It's not that hard."
Then he turned at Achilles, "See?
That's how you get jealous.
You get whoever makes you feel they are more qualified than you to teach you what makes them more qualified than you."
"No, I don't think you're more qualified than me when it comes to him at least."
He ignored me, "Man, I'm such a good catch it's almost a pity I already resigned myself to taking care of my brother from a different mother.
Right, young Peneus?"
He turned around only to find the kid serving himself grilled meat from Zagreus' batch from Hestia's hearth.
"How about knowing his name for starters?"
I asked.
The doctor followed his young brother where he began snatching the food off his plate.
Meanwhile, Achilles has stopped eating and just kept on poking the hot coals sizzling on the griddle.
"May I ask why you are so guarded against Aesclepius?"
"I'm not guarded against him.
If we ever get into a fight--no, we can't--it would only look like I'm picking on him."
"But you glare at him pretty intensely more often than you do with, say, Theseus.
I'm wondering if he did something to you."
Achilles was silent that I thought he must not want to talk about it.
I'm ready to wait for him but he spoke again, "Because he's...he's..." he looked like he wanted to swallow the words more than spit them out.
"Because he's definitely a good man," he finally said, frustrated to admit it.
"Better than me in many respects that you care about.
Didn't you admire Chiron because he's a healer too?
So much that now you also wanted to take up the art of medicine.
Back in the army, you were more known by the people you saved than the people you killed.
And I'm just...just...well, I'm the opposite of that..."
He continued, "Aesclepius is a doctor, the greatest in fact.
He has only saved lives.
He never took them.
He's everything that I am not.
I mean, uh, what I'm saying is..."
You're saying you're jealous.
Goddamn it.
Seriously.
I threw both palms on my face.
I'll give you my soul if I have to.
I'd rather burn hell than give up on you.
I'd die by your hands if that will save you.
And you're worried about the greatest doctor waltzing in and probably catching my eyes?
"Achilles," I said, desperately struggling to keep a straight face.
"You can't be this sinfully endearing all the time.
It's bad for my heart and for my sense of reason."
"Huh?"
*** It was the darkness before dawn.
Or at least what is left of it.
Morning is on its way.
I opened my eyes and woke up to the bodies that were strewn everywhere, either passed out drunk or just sleeping.
Achilles was leaning on my shoulder.
I found my hand on his.
What I did not find however was the ring on his finger.
I remember him going out of his way and tossing it out somewhere in the middle of the night last night while saying something along the lines of, "Let's see if your ring can really find it."
It hasn't even been a full day since the ruler of Elysium specifically told us not to test it and he has already thrown it to find out.
That's just one of the things I love about him.
My ring felt warm on my finger.
It is also blinking, dazzling and dimming alternately.
I held my hand up and forward and it went slower.
I held my hand to my right and there was it again, blinking fast as if telling me to hurry up.
I roused myself, kissed Achilles on the forehead and followed the ring that is searching for its pair.
It brought me to one of the hills in our Elysium, one of the vantage points from where you can survey the fields below and beyond.
It is unsurprising to me that Achilles was able to throw that high and far.
I sifted through the earth, following my ring's signal.

Until finally there it was, right by the fig tree, glinting like the first rays of the sunrise that is already peeking from the horizon, dramatic reds and orange already pouring from it, bathing our Elysium.
I picked up Achilles' ring.
"Oh, you actually found it."
I turned around, slightly surprised, "Since when?"
"Since you kissed me good morning.
I've been stealthily following you."
The sunrise tinged his cheeks warm orange.
He smiled and its warmth coursed through me.
I let it soaked me in.
"This here is really the best view to watch the sunrise."
"Did you throw the ring out here on purpose?
Is this your way of inviting me to watch it together?"
"Of course not," he said, trying to be wily and shy at the same time and perfectly pulling it off.
"I could just drag you out here if I want to."
I gazed at him, light spilling on his face and I heard Aesclepius' words ring in my ears.
Wishbone rings are oath rings.
"Achilles," I said, sunrise on his face, wind on his hair.
I took his hand and slid the ring up his finger.
"We need no oath.
We need no vows, but let me say it anyway."
I kissed the hand that is wearing the ring and I declared.
"Let me take care of you for the rest of our time."
Here in our afterlife, afterwards, a new sun rises for us.
I gaze at the rings on our fingers, fingers that are entwined with each other.
I begin to think about how these rings hold our secrets with us.
About how they hide the scars we share.
About the soul we share.
He crinkled his nose and he looked like he was struggling to keep his tears from falling.
I laughed.
Achilles threw his arms around me tightly and wordlessly and I embraced him back.
I took him in.
All of him.
And we both understood.
I am half of him and he is half of me.
We deserve a soft afterwards my love.
We were once alive and we have suffered enough.
END.

Achilles and Patroclus being mentors to the Prince.
